Titular: Target cuts sales outlook after weak Christmas sales
Subtitular: Sluggish growth for one of sector’s best recent performers sparks concern over US consumer spending
Texto: Target has slashed its quarterly sales outlook after far weaker than forecast festive sales, ringing alarm bells on Wall Street about the state of US retail as the company had been coping better than most with upheaval in the industry.Like-for-like sales rose only 1.4 per cent in November and December, the retailer said on Wednesday, an unexpectedly sharp slowdown from the 5.7 per cent expansion recorded over the same period a year earlier. Toys and electronics were especially weak.The update from Target, which sells a vast range of products from food and toiletries to furniture and kitchenware, raises new questions about US consumer spending — whose strength has underpinned global economic growth for months.Shares in the company, which had rallied 82 per cent over the past year, slid 7.6 per cent by mid-morning in New York, wiping $4.8bn from its market capitalisation.The particular weakness in electronics, where like-for-like sales fell more than 6 per cent from a year ago, sent shares in electronics retailer Best Buy down 2 per cent.Toymaker shares also came under pressure after Target said toy sales had failed to rise from last year’s levels, with Mattel down 6.4 per cent and Hasbro falling 3.4 per cent.Target now expects like-for-like sales for the quarter to be dragged down to 1.4 per cent, less than half of the 3 to 4 per cent it had previously forecast and well below the 3.8 per cent expected by analysts in a Bloomberg poll.The results were a “tough miss”, said Brian Cornell, chairman and chief executive of Target. “While we knew this season was going be challenging, it was even more challenging than we expected.”The figures from Target, which has become a US retail powerhouse with more than 1,800 stores, were particularly concerning as the company is seen as one of the best-performing companies in the sector.While mall-based clothing and department stores in particular have long struggled to adapt to the age of ecommerce, and several posted declines in holiday sales last week, Target has been finding success with its mix of value and convenience. Several of the company’s own brands have also been popular, and Target has made strides online.Still, analysts noted the weak sales figures were being compared with a strong performance this time last year.Despite the lower sales outlook, the company maintained its fourth-quarter and full-year earnings per share guidance at $1.55 to $1.75 and $6.27 to $6.47 respectively. Mr Cornell said this demonstrated the “durability of our business model”.Neil Saunders, managing director of the GlobalData Retail consultancy, noted that Target’s sales had remained robust in some categories, up 5 per cent in clothing and 7 per cent in beauty.However, he said that flat electronics sales were partly the result of a “far from inspiring” line-up of tech this year that was out of Target’s control.“Target remains a good retailer on the right trajectory,” he said. “It may have stumbled and slowed over the holidays but it is still one of the most attractive runners.”Alongside the figures, Target also announced the departure of Janna Potts, its chief stores officer, after 30 years with the company. She will be replaced by Target property executive Mark Schindele.

Titular: Target shares hit the mark after chain raises forecasts
Subtitular: US retailer forecasts tenth straight quarter of same-store sales growth
Texto: US retailer Target has raised its profit forecasts for 2019, as its third-quarter results painted a robust picture of the American consumer.Reaping the benefits of a turnround strategy spearheaded by chief executive Brian Cornell, Target on Wednesday said same-store sales rose 4.5 per cent in the three months ended November 2. That was down from a 5.1 per cent a year ago, but better than the 3.4 per cent the group achieved last quarter.The big box retailer forecast same-store sales — a closely watched industry metric — would rise for a tenth straight quarter in the final three months of its current fiscal year. Target shares surged almost 14 per cent on the news.The group’s results come as investors scrutinise the health of the US consumer, which has been sustained by a strong jobs market and proved one of the brightest spots in the economic expansion. However, a handful of disappointing results from retailers on Tuesday, and weak underlying measures in October’s retail sales data, again stirred debate about the resilience of spending ahead of the crucial holiday season.Target’s fortunes have diverged from those of other large US retail chains. Its strategy, which included offering more profitable in-house branded products, has underpinned a 20 per cent rise in annual net income between the 2015 and 2018 financial years.Michelle Gass, chief executive of department store chain Kohl’s, on Tuesday blamed an “increasingly competitive environment” as one of the reasons behind disappointing third-quarter results. On the same day, Home Depot also cut its financial forecasts for the second time this year, partly because of declining lumber prices rather than weak consumer spending.The market has rewarded winning retailers and ramped up speculative bets against losers.Minneapolis-based Target forecast same-store sales growth of between 3 per cent and 4 per cent in the current quarter. That would follow year-on-year growth of 4.5 per cent in the three months ended November 2.In a conference call with analysts, Mr Cornell highlighted “the really exceptional performance in categories like apparel, where we performed extremely well, growing at a rate of over 10 per cent, picking up significant market share.”In the third quarter, Target’s revenue rose 4.7 per cent from a year ago to $18.7bn, topping Wall Street forecasts for $18.5bn. Earnings increased 18.5 per cent year-on-year to $1.39 a share, topping the median analyst forecast. Its operating margin of 5.4 per cent in the third quarter was up from 4.6 per cent a year ago.Target raised its 2019 adjusted earnings forecast for the second consecutive quarter.

Titular: Target tells suppliers to bear cost of Donald Trump’s tariffs
Subtitular: Demand to hundreds of providers sets stage for tense talks over prices of Chinese imports
Texto: Target has set the stage for contentious talks with the US retailer’s suppliers of Chinese goods, telling them it would refuse to “accept any cost increases related to tariffs” imposed by Donald Trump in his trade war with Beijing.Hundreds of suppliers to the S&P 500 company received the warning in a memo sent last week, shortly before 15 per cent tariffs on $112bn of goods from China went into effect at the weekend.“Our expectation is that you will develop the appropriate contingency plans so that we don’t have to pass price increases along” to customers, wrote Mark Tritton, Target’s chief merchandising officer.To be so direct [with suppliers] is fairly unusualWith a network of more than 1,800 stores across the US and sales of $74.4bn last year, Target is a crucial route to market for suppliers of goods ranging from groceries and toiletries to electronics and homewares. Its shares are trading just shy of an all-time high, giving the company a $54.9bn market capitalisation.The scale of Target’s US presence and popularity among American shoppers have given it substantial clout in negotiations with providers.Even so, some analysts warned its apparent refusal to accept a share of tariff costs risked alienating suppliers.“Some will be pretty cross,” said Neil Saunders, managing director of GlobalData Retail, adding that despite Target’s “cosy” public image, the memo was a sign that the company could be “quite ruthless”.“To be so direct [with suppliers] is fairly unusual,” he said.Jan Kniffen, a retail consultant, described the demand in the memo as an “opening gambit” and predicted that suppliers would not necessarily give in. “It’s going to be a negotiation,” he said.Retailers and their suppliers have also been shifting production and sourcing away from China in an effort to contain the financial fallout from the trade war.Steve Bratspies, chief merchandising officer of Walmart’s US business, told a conference on Wednesday that while the retailer had successfully navigated earlier rounds of tariffs, the latest tranche “gets tougher” and “covers a lot more” products.Still, he described price rises as a “last resort”. “There’s a whole bunch of different levers that a buyer can pull,” he said.Bruce Besanko, chief financial officer of Kohl’s, told another conference organised by Goldman Sachs this week: “We’re certainly partnering with our vendors and suppliers to be sure that we try to avoid having an impact to our customers.”Mr Tritton’s memo was sent to Target suppliers that are “importers of record” — those legally responsible for ensuring that goods are imported in accordance with the law — for goods from China. It said: “We have delivered on this [customer]-centric plan with your co-operation, hard work and partnership and appreciate the work we’ve done, together.”

Titular: Short sellers bloodied as Target shares jump 20%
Subtitular: Bets against the retailer’s shares rose ahead of blowout earnings
Texto: Short sellers of shares in Target, the US retailer, suffered paper losses of almost half a billion dollars after the company’s better than expected sales and profit numbers sent the stock soaring to a record high.Short bets against the retailer’s shares rose significantly over the past week ahead of the company’s latest earnings report, repeating a pattern that has emerged in the past several quarters, according to IHS Markit data.Short selling involves borrowing shares in a company from an existing owner in order to sell the stock in anticipation it will fall.Short interest accounted for 2.8 per cent of Target’s shares, or $1.2bn. on Tuesday, compared to 2 per cent, or $870m, at the start of the previous week.The paper loss totalled $479m as Target shares closed on Wednesday up 20.6 per cent at $103.11, according to S3 Partners, an independent financial data provider.“People have been bloodied on the bell,” said Ihor Dusaniwsky, head of predictive analytics for S3. “They may hope the price weakens in coming days to see if their short positions improve, instead of dropping their positions today.”S3 also calculated that short sellers had lost $971m so far in 2019 on bets against Target shares. That ranks among the year’s most unsuccessful bearish positions, it said, though still far behind Alibaba, where short sellers have lost $6bn this year, and Apple, whose rising stock price has wiped $3.1bn from the portfolios of those betting against it.The precipitous drop reveals the risky nature of short selling, which can lead to sizeable losses when stocks suddenly rise, even if an underlying bearish thesis is borne out over time — as the shift toward online shopping that has hit profits at brick and mortar retailers may still be.The losses were incurred by a broad group of short sellers including a sizeable portion of quantitative hedge funds that take out large short positions in companies in common stock indices, like the S&P 500, in which Target features.“A lot of losses will be going into quant books, but a lot of equity long-short hedge funds are playing this name as well,” Mr Dusaniwsky said.Target increased its profit forecast for the year to between $5.90 and $6.20 per share on Wednesday, from $5.75 and $6.05 previously, in part because of positive results from its expanded online shopping offering and same-day deliveries. Brian Cornell, chief executive, said the company had gone from “simply selling on a website to integrating digital within every part of our business, positioning our stores at the centre of the most comprehensive suite of digital fulfilment options in the US”.“Brian Cornell is operating and executing at a very high level and is the best operator in the retail space right now and deserves 100 per cent of the credit for Target’s success,” said Marc Cohodes, a California-based short-seller who does not hold a short position in the company. “He took a lot of crap for a long time and now his efforts are being recognised in the marketplace.”

Titular: Target and Lowe’s sales show US shoppers still spending
Subtitular: Shares in retailers surge as American consumers remain bright spot in global economy
Texto: Blowout financial results from US retailers Target and Lowe’s sent their share prices up sharply on Wednesday and provided evidence that Americans are continuing to spend despite fears over the outlook for the economy.Shares in big-box retailer Target were up 20 per cent to close at an all-time high. Meanwhile, home improvement chain Lowe’s closed 10 per cent higher.Both companies posted stronger-than-expected sales growth during the second quarter. That boosted the consumer discretionary sector as a whole, which rose 1.5 per cent.The results also provided more evidence that spending by US consumers is one of the global economy’s bright spots, even as investors worry about recession risks and the Trump administration’s trade war with Beijing.This month’s inversion of the yield curve, which plots US government bond yields of different maturities and is seen as a harbinger of recession, sparked a new round of gloom. But Brian Moynihan, chief executive of Bank of America, told CNBC on Wednesday that he believed too much attention was being given to Treasury rates, pointing to consumer spending as a more important indicator.In a world where consumers have more choices than ever, inferior brick-and-mortar experiences will go away“What it’s going to come down to is what’s really going on in the economy,” Mr Moynihan said. “The underlying consumer is doing well and making more money. They’re employed. And more importantly, they’re spending more money.”Last week Walmart, a bellwether for middle-class spending, said US consumers were in “solid” financial health as it raised its outlook, and the US government released data showing retail sales remained robust.Some signs of consumer skittishness are emerging. A University of Michigan survey earlier this month showed consumer sentiment turning less positive. Notably, it showed the Federal Reserve’s quarter point rate cut in July, aimed at supporting the economy, raised consumers’ fears about a possible slowdown and led them to conclude they may need to reduce spending in anticipation of a recession.Results on Wednesday signalled, however, that the consumer economy is humming along. Same-store sales rose 2.3 per cent at Lowe’s, ahead of estimates of 1.7 per cent. Target said sales at established stores were up 3.4 per cent, topping forecasts for a 3 per cent advance.Target — which sells homewares, clothes, electronics and beauty products across the US — showed it was reaping rewards from investing in its online offering, same-day deliveries and in-store experience. It increased its full-year adjusted profit forecast to between $5.90 and $6.20 per share, compared with the prior range of $5.75 to $6.05.Sales through Target’s digital channels grew 34 per cent in the second quarter on a comparable basis. Its same-day delivery service accounted for nearly 1.5 percentage points of the group’s 3.4 per cent comparable sales growth.“In a world where consumers have more choices than ever, inferior brick-and-mortar experiences will go away,” said John Mulligan, chief operating officer at Target. “That’s why we’re investing heavily, both in our store assets and in the experience our team provides.”Lowe’s, which was forced to cut its profit guidance in May as rising costs hurt its first-quarter earnings, sounded a more optimistic note this time. “The underlying macroeconomic fundamentals in the US remain supportive as demonstrated by the solid pace of job growth,” said David Denton, chief financial officer.The strong results for US retailers have not been universal. Macy’s the department store chain, said last week it was having to discount merchandise, sending its shares down 13 per cent. And Home Depot, the world’s biggest home improvement retailer, cited the US-China trade stand-off among the factors in a downgrade of its sales forecast for 2019.On Wednesday, though, Home Depot shares set a new intraday record high.

Titular: Target bucks US retail gloom with strong sales growth
Subtitular: Cheap-chic offerings and same-day delivery help drive first-quarter earnings
Texto: Target continued to gain the upper hand in the battle for US retail dollars, with its digital investment and aggressive push to offer same-day delivery powering sales for its latest quarter.Like-for-like sales, a closely followed industry metric, rose 4.8 per cent in the three months to May 4 as shoppers flocked to its stores. The rise marks the eighth straight quarter of same-store sales growth for Target and topped expectations for a 4.1 per cent rise.It further validates chief executive Brian Cornell’s audacious plan, announced in 2017, to invest more than $7bn over three years in technology, supply chain and private-brand labels to compete against Amazon on the e-commerce front and against Walmart and TJMaxx on the price front.Shares in Target jumped as much as 10.1 per cent on the news. While the rise was trimmed to 9 per cent by mid afternoon trade, that is still enough put the stock on course for its best day since December 2008.“Target had an outstanding first quarter,” said Mr Cornell. “Over the past two years we have made important investments to build a durable operating and financial model that drives consumer relevance and sustainable growth. Target’s first quarter performance and market-share gains demonstrate that the model is working.”Target’s strong first quarter stands in contrast to the pain being felt in other parts of the US retail sector. Nordstrom, Kohl’s and JC Penney — three of the largest department store chains in the US — all reported falls in quarterly sales on Tuesday, unnerving investors and triggering a sharp sell-off in retail stocks.While department store operators have been squeezed by falling traffic to shopping centres and online competition, sales at Target — or Tar-zhay as its devotees call it — have been supported by its “high-low” strategy. Even as the $37bn big box retailer has aggressively lowered prices on basic household items such as paper towels to drive shoppers to its stores, it is betting that consumers will also snap up home decor, clothing and other knick-knacks from its in-house brands that offer higher profit margins.Its strategy of using stores as hubs to fulfil online orders has also kept it competitive even as Amazon and Walmart started offering free next-day shipping.Online sales rose 42 per cent during the quarter, with its same-day delivery services contributing to more than half of that growth.Overall, sales came in at $17.4bn for the three months, a 5.1 per cent year-on-year rise. Net income jumped nearly 11 per cent to $795m, or $1.53 per diluted share, ahead of estimates of $1.43 a share.The profit gain came despite the rise in operating costs and slight dip in gross margin.“Throughout this year, we will continue to extend the reach of our same-day fulfilment options, strengthen our portfolio of owned and exclusive brands, remodel and open more stores and invest in our team,” said Mr Cornell. “We’re confident that we’re well positioned to deliver strong financial performance in 2019 and beyond,” he added.Shares in Target are up about 9 per cent so far this year after eking out a 1.3 per cent gain in 2018.

Titular: Target boosted by best sales growth since 2005
Subtitular: Retail stocks lifted by strong final quarter performances
Texto: Target posted its biggest annual rise in like-for-like sales since 2005 while rival Kohl’s also posted stronger-than-forecast figures as the latest batch of retail sector results reassured Wall Street.Shares in big-box retailer Target opened 5 per cent higher while department store chain Kohl’s was up 2.2 per cent as investors cheered the fourth quarter figures and stronger than forecast outlooks for the year ahead.Same-store sales growth at Target accelerated to 5.3 per cent in the fourth quarter, rising 5 per cent in 2018 as a whole. Brian Cornell, chairman and chief executive, said the big box retailer was reaping financial rewards from the investments it has made in revamping its stores and improving its online offering. Digital sales rose almost a third in the fourth quarter.The investments, together with rising logistics and wage costs, sent Target’s fourth quarter gross margin down from 26.1 per cent in 2017 to 25.7 per cent. Operating income for the year as a whole eased 2.7 per cent to $4.1bn.However, Target’s earnings per share outlook for 2019 of between $5.75 to $6.05 per share was higher than analysts had expected.Kohl’s target to deliver earnings between $5.80 and $6.15 per share for 2019 was also better than expected. The company, led by chief executive Michelle Gass, has struck a deal with Amazon to allow customers to return items purchased from the ecommerce giant at its stores.Annual like-for-like sales rose 1.7 per cent, although operating income dipped from $1.42bn in 2017 to $1.36bn.

Titular: Target bests rivals with upbeat holiday sales
Texto: Target led the way among a series of retailer updates for the festive season as solid sales growth during the final two months of 2018 led it to recommit to its full-year sales and earnings guidance.The Minneapolis-based retailer’s numbers reinforce pre-Christmas predictions from top industry executives for a bumper shopping season supported by a robust economy — notwithstanding debate about the impact successive Federal Reserve interest rate rises might have on sentiment, and broader concerns over rent and footfall afflicting the sector.The big-box store said comparable sales, a closely watched industry metric, rose 5.7 per cent in the final months of 2018 from a year earlier, with growth in all five of its core merchandise categories.The increase was driven by more shoppers both in-store and online, as well as a “small increase” in average ticket prices, the company said. Seasonal gifts, along with toys and baby items, saw the strongest growth.The sales bump helped Target reaffirm guidance for its fourth quarter of 5 per cent year-on-year growth in comparable sales, and full-year adjusted earnings in the range of $5.30 to $5.50 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters forecast full-year adjusted earnings of $5.39 a share.Target also announced a series of leadership changes alongside its financial figures, including news its chief financial officer Cathy Smith would be retiring.Brian Cornell, chief executive, said he was pleased with the holiday season performance. In 2019 “we expect to build on this momentum as we gain further scale in our fulfilment capabilities and deliver profitable growth throughout the year,” he said.Target said it had started an internal and external search for its next CFO. Ms Smith joined the company in 2015, having previously been CFO at pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts.Elsewhere among US retailers, L Brands, the parent company of troubled lingerie purveyor Victoria’s Secret, reported flat comparable sales growth in the five weeks ended January 5 compared to a year earlier, while net sales for the same period were down 1.6 per cent at $2.5bn. But the company added that it expects to report fourth-quarter adjusted earnings towards the higher end of recently upgraded previous guidance of $1.90 to $2.10.Kohl’s reported a 1.2 per cent increase in comparable sales for the final two months of the year. While sales improved slightly, the department store operator said it faced a tough comparison with strong numbers during the 2017 holiday season.Target shares were down 1.6 per cent in pre-market trade, faring better than L Brands and Kohl’s, which both shed 5.4 per cent.

Titular: Target shares drop 12% as retailer’s investments hit margins
Subtitular: Disappointing results come ahead of crucial holiday shopping season
Texto: A ramp up in investments helped keep the tills ringing at Target during the latest quarter but this came at the expense of profit margins, which suffered a surprise drop, spooking investors who sent the shares sharply lower.The Minneapolis-based retailer saw its shares slump by as much as 12 per cent in early morning New York trading, putting it on track for its worst day since February 2017 when it had reported an even worse result than it had previously warned.This time the squeeze on profit margins, along with a miss in headline sales results, raised questions over whether the company could sustain its turnround strategy as it heads into the crucial holiday shopping season.Best known for its cheap-chic offerings and stylish designer collaborations, Target — or Tar-zhay as devotees have nicknamed it — has been slashing prices on household staples and making investments in delivery and fulfilment centres in order to better compete against rivals such as Amazon’s Pantry and Walmart’s Jet.com.The company’s “high-low” strategy of building up higher margin in-house brands while staying competitive on prices for basic everyday goods has helped drive a turnround in sales, but has hurt overall profit margins.The unexpected drop in gross margin, which fell 90 basis points to 28.7 per cent in the three months to October 28 from the year ago period, and contributed to the miss in adjusted earnings, appeared to have unsettled investors most.While net earnings jumped by more than 30 per cent to $622m, that was largely due to a lower corporate tax bill. Stripping this out, adjusted diluted earnings were $1.09 a share — well below estimates of $1.12.Sales rose a solid 5.7 per cent to $17.59bn during the quarter, as shoppers snapped up everything from toys to pressure cookers, but also missed Wall Street’s loftier expectations for $17.72bn worth of turnover.Like-for-like sales rose 5.1 per cent, a hair below the 5.2 per cent that analysts had forecast, and a slowing in the pace of growth from the 6.5 per cent recorded during the second quarter.Hopes had been high for Target ahead of the latest results, based on a strengthening US economy and robust consumer spending data. Stoking those expectations were rosier results last week from Walmart, Macy’s and Home Depot, with each of those retailers raising their earnings outlook for the full year.Target reiterated on Tuesday its full-year adjusted earnings guidance of $5.30 to $5.50 per share, a target which it last raised three months ago.But, in a sign that the retailer will be facing stiff competition in the battle for holiday spending, it said it expected fourth quarter comparable sales growth of around 5 per cent, which would represent another slight slowdown from the pace recorded in the previous two quarters.“We are encouraged the company reiterated full-year guidance; however we believe market expectations in this environment are high and stock is likely to see weakness,” said analysts at Cowen.Shares in Target have fallen 14 per cent since they hit a record high of $90.39 earlier in September.

Titular: The top FT stories read by the legal world in the coronavirus lockdown
Subtitular: Professionals are hungry for reporting on how peers are responding to the crisis
Texto: How is the legal sector responding to the coronavirus crisis? Since the pandemic hit, the FT has been covering the impact on law firms — from the sudden widespread adjustment to remote working and the disruption to courts, to an influx of client questions about keeping deals alive and managing legal issues emerging from the outbreak.The following stories are taken from our Full Disclosure newsletter, sent to FT subscribers in the industry each week, sharing what has been most popular with legal readers on FT.com.As with most sectors, shouldering the financial blow to business is an urgent priority: readers have zeroed in on our reporting about how law firms are coping, while finding opportunities in growth areas.This week law firms made moves to ease the burden of coronavirus on their bottom lines.None has been so unusual as Norton Rose Fulbright, which is resurrecting a four-day week scheme it enacted during the financial crisis in a bid to save jobs.Staff at the firm earning more than £45,000 have been asked to volunteer to work four days a week when they are less busy and take a 20 per cent cut. Those on lower salaries will take a 5-20 per cent pay cut for the same reduction in hours.Elsewhere the legal world continues to adapt to remote technology. This week the Solicitors’ Disciplinary Tribunal went virtual, with Baker McKenzie’s ex-London boss Gary Senior facing a hearing via Zoom over alleged sexual misconduct. He denies the allegations against him.The move to homeworking has been a big change for lawyers, who are used to face-to-face meetings and close teamwork. But online tools including electronic data rooms for checking documents and video conferencing platforms are making it easier to adapt.Tech tools are also helping from a social perspective — whether it is Friday night drinks on Zoom to “virtual coffee rooms”, lawyers are finding ways to connect with colleagues and bond with teams in the digital realm.Here is our selection of what FT subscribers in the legal sector having been reading in the past week:Lawyers re-tool to take on restructuring boomLaw firms are retraining junior lawyers to become experts in restructuring and insolvency during the pandemic and borrowing partners from quieter departments to work on large deals at firms including Latham & Watkins and Hogan Lovells. As one senior private equity lawyer put it:“Firms expect three or four times the number of core restructuring lawyers to be subsumed into stressed and distressed related work during the Covid-19 crisis.”Norton Rose calls on staff to take on four-day weekNorton Rose Fulbright became the first large law firm in the UK to ask staff to accept a pay cut and reduced hours last week. It will also be delaying the payout of partner profits as well as salary rises and bonus payments.“Norton Rose took similar action during the financial crisis. Other big firms are also making moves to conserve cash and protect jobs in the face of big predicted falls in fee income.”LSE rejects Burford’s claim of stock manipulationThe latest salvo was fired last week in a bitter court row between litigation funder Burford Capital and the London Stock Exchange. Burford believes its share price was manipulated and wants the court to force the LSE to reveal the traders who did it. The LSE called Burford’s claims “completely detached from reality”.“The LSE said it had thoroughly investigated the claim along with the FCA and found no evidence of wrongdoing. For both the LSE and FCA to be wrong, it said, ‘there must have been a catastrophic and incredibly surprising independent failure of their systems and analysis, both automated and manual’, for which there was no evidence.”Neighbourly love in a cold climateThis week the FT’s Jo Ellison looks at what enforced social coldness means for body language. Handshakes are long gone and the elbow bump too — how do we express affection in the age of coronavirus?“Maybe it’s time to introduce my grandmother’s old favourite — when you do something she approves of, you get a little wink. It’s friendly, informal, cheeky, and it shows solidarity. Plus, you can read it from a distance.”Home working leaves UK vulnerable to fraudMass home working as a result of coronavirus has opened up opportunities for fraudsters to target companies and fuelled a sharp rise in attempted scams in recent weeks.“While regulators have been quick to warn about schemes aimed at individuals amid the pandemic — such as financial data ‘phishing’ attempts, or bank payment frauds — the danger to businesses and their investors is equally heightened, say advisers.”Closing argumentThose of us feeling smug about our lockdown exercise efforts will be put to shame this week by 73-year old Rosie Swale-Pope (top picture). The adventurer is currently holed up in a Turkish hotel, but since July 2018 she has spent nine nights in every 10 sleeping inside a three-wheeled trailer she is hauling from Brighton to Kathmandu, Nepal, in a 5,300-mile run through 18 countries.“From 2002 to 2007, Swale-Pope ran almost 20,000 miles from her then home in Tenby, Wales, through northern Europe, Russia, Alaska, Canada and the US, returning to the UK via Greenland and Iceland. She endured broken bones, frostbite and encounters with hungry wolves — and turned 60 on the road.”

Titular: Target ‘hits bullseye’ with strong sales growth
Subtitular: E-commerce helps big-box retailer beat expectations and lift outlook
Texto: Target shares climbed on Wednesday after the big-box retailer’s latest earnings report sailed past lofty expectations, thanks to a strong boost from digital sales and its best quarterly comparable sales growth in 13 years.For the three months to August 4, revenue roses 6.9 per cent year on year to $17.8bn. Net earnings came in at $799m, up 19.2 per cent, and earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.49 were 23 per cent higher compared with a year ago.Digital sales also continued to rise, as the retailer seeks to keep pace with e-commerce rivals like Amazon. During the quarter, comparable digital channel sales were up 41 per cent year on year to make up 1.5 percentage points of the 6.5 per cent overall like-for-like sales growth during the quarter — which was Target’s best in 13 years, the company said.Quarterly traffic also made strong gains, rising 6.4 per cent, the fastest pace since the metric was first reported in 2008, Target added.Analysts had expected sales of $17.23bn and net income of $749m, or $1.40 a share. Revenues had been tipped to rise 4.1 per cent from a year ago, according to Factset.Target on Wednesday also lifted its full-year outlook. It is now targeting adjusted earnings per share of $5.30 to $5.50, up from its previous forecast for earnings between $5.15 and $5.45.Hopes had been high for Target and other retailers amid a strengthening US economy and robust consumer spending. Stoking those expectations were results last week from rival Walmart, whose shares shot higher after it unveiled its strongest US sales growth for more than a decade.Moody’s lead retail analyst Charlie O’Shea said Target’s earnings had “hit the bulls-eye”.“Reflecting the company’s myriad investments, margins reflect slight, almost de minimis compression, which is the short-term pain for long-term gain, and we note that working capital continues to improve, with accounts payable exceeding inventory, indicating improved leverage with vendors.”He added that the improved outlook for the full year was “consistent with our view that there are macroeconomic tailwinds that can be exploited by the strongest, most financially flexible retailers that are hitting on all cylinders, with Target definitely in that class.”Target shares, which fell nearly 10 per cent in 2017, are up more than 27.6 per cent in the year to date as of Tuesday’s close. They rose more than 5 per cent on Wednesday to hit a record high before falling back to sit 3 per cent higher in afternoon trading.Also reaching a record high on Wednesday was Lowe’s, the US home-improvement chain, which reversed course after an early decline to surge more than 8 per cent.Although Lowe’s trimmed its full-year sales growth forecast, it said revenue rose 7.1 per cent year on year to $20.9bn in the quarter. Marvin Ellison, the recently installed chief executive said Target was committed to improving its performance by “sharpening our focus on retail fundamentals” and limiting projects and initiatives that distract from its core home-improvement business.Along with Walmart and Home Depot, these major US big-box brands have illustrated how retailers with a large bricks-and-mortar presence can thrive even as e-commerce changes how consumers shop — in part, by using physical stores to complement digital platforms.Their performance contrasts with the gloom that has hung over the retail sector in recent years, as investors fret that companies are not nimble enough to keep pace with Amazon. Not all retailers are thriving, though — US department store chain JC Penney plumbed a record low last week after disappointing earnings, while Macy’s generally upbeat results met a cold reception.

Titular: Target bid to boost online sales pressures margins
Subtitular: Shares drop after US retailer discloses smaller than expected rise in earnings
Texto: Target said on Wednesday its efforts to grow its online operations boosted sales but weighed on margins and pushed it to a weaker-than-expected quarterly profit.Shares in the Minneapolis-based retailer were down 6 per cent in early trade after the company reported net income of $718m or $1.33 a share in the three months ended May 5. While that was up from $678m or $1.23 a share in the year ago period, it missed analyst expectations for $1.38 a share.The impact of Target’s investments in its online business were laid bare as the company noted that its gross margin declined to 29.8 per cent, compared with 30 per cent in the year ago quarter, weighed down by costs tied to digital fulfilment.Target has ramped up investments in its delivery services and infrastructure as it competes with Amazon and Walmart. Earlier this month, the company lowered its delivery fees.“We anticipate target shares underperform given the [quarterly] result is likely to increase fears an already competitive retail environment will become more costly,” said Mark Astrachan, analyst at Stifel.The investments did however help grow online sales by 28 per cent and total revenue climbed 3.4 per cent from a year ago to $16.8bn, reflecting comparable sales growth of 3 per cent. That topped analyst estimates for sales of $16.6bn and like-for-like sales of 2.9 per cent. Traffic also increased 3.7 per cent — its strongest quarterly performance in more than a decade.“We’re very pleased that our business continued to generate strong traffic and sales growth in the first quarter, as we made significant progress in support of our long-term strategic initiatives,” said Brian Cornell, chief executive. “Strong sales growth in our home, essentials and food & beverage categories offset the impact of delayed sales in temperature-sensitive categories, which accelerated rapidly in recent weeks as weather improved across the country.”Looking ahead, the company expects comparable sales growth to accelerate in the current quarter, rising in the low-to-mid single digits and adjusted earnings of between $1.30 to $1.50 a share.Target shares are up nearly 16 per cent year-to-date.

Titular: Target/Kroger: left on the shelf
Subtitular: Two retailers besieged would not be better off as one
Texto: When it comes to fashioning a turnround, Target insists it is “playing our own game”. It should stick to playing alone. On Friday, reports surfaced that the bargain chic discounter was pondering a tie-up with Kroger, the US’s largest supermarket chain. Such a deal would be a blockbuster. Both chains have enterprise values greater than $35bn and both are in the midst of a wrenching transition from dependence on physical stores. But results to date indicate far more promise for Target than Kroger. A merger may offer standard scale benefits but grocery is one of the worst segments of American retail. Target should steer clear.Not that the company has had an easy time itself. After a massive cyber hack, executive churn and the relentless Amazon onslaught, Target’s share price fell 40 per cent between 2015 and 2017. But it has spent the past year investing heavily in remodelling its stores and building a hybrid physical and online model. Same-store sales growth started to snap back — up 3.6 per cent in the latest quarter. Shares are up 30 per cent in the past year. The question remains, however, just how profitable a revitalised Target can be given that its current operating margin is 6 per cent. Five years ago it was above 8 per cent.Even Target’s lower margin would be a dream for Kroger. The company reported a 2017 operating margin of less than 3 per cent amid unwelcome new competition from German discounters Lidl and Aldi.Kroger may have consolidated the traditional supermarket sector but investor sentiment towards it has soured. Its shares are down a fifth in the past year. Shareholders would undoubtedly welcome a bailout from the race to the bottom in grocery from Target. Target should not comply. About a fifth of its sales come from grocery but making a bigger bet means a tricky integration that is simply not worth the risk.The Lex team is interested in hearing more from readers. Could a combined Target/Kroger work?

Titular: Kroger, Target jump on merger report
Texto: Investors are stocking up on shares of Target and Kroger on Friday after a report said the two US retailers are in talks about a possible merger in a bid to fend off competition from Amazon.Shares in grocery chain Kroger spiked as much as 8 per cent in pre-market trading while those for Target, the big-box retailer best known for its cheap-chic offerings, jumped 2.3 per cent.According to Fast Company, the two companies began talks last summer about a partnership and the talks are ongoing this year.However, the two companies appear to be struggling to decide whether a merger is the best path forward, the trade magazine reported.Kroger declined to comment.A merger between Target and Kroger would create a retail juggernaut with nearly $195bn in combined sales last year and a market value of $58bn. That compares to the $177.9bn in annual sales recorded by Amazon and Walmart’s $118.1bn.Traditional US grocers have been roiled by Amazon’s purchase of Whole Foods last year and Kroger has seen its margins squeezed amid an escalating price war.While Target has managed to buck the malaise that has gripped the wider retail sector by focusing on the ever-important “mom” demographic - a group that it has successfully lured with its product mix ranging from kiddie clothing and cheap-chic home decor to laundry detergent and snacks - the grocery division remains its biggest weakness.In this respect, a tie-up between the two could see Target improve its grocery business while Kroger will get access to Target’s customers and e-commerce infrastructure.As of Thursday’s close, Target has a market cap of $37.5bn while Kroger is worth around $20.6bn.

Titular: Target boosts sales at expense of profit margins
Texto:
Target kept the tills ringing over the holiday season - albeit at a price.The Minneapolis-based retailer on Tuesday reported a hefty 10 per cent jump in sales to $22.77bn during its fiscal fourth quarter, as shoppers snapped up everything from toys to pressure cookers and pieces from the company’s new home decor collaboration with Fixer Upper star Joanna Gaines.Within this, same-store sales - a key industry metrics - rose 3.6 per cent in the three months to Feburary 3, the most in three years and topping Wall Street estimates for a 3.1 per cent increase.However, shares fell in pre-market trading as investors appeared unnerved by the slight drop in profit margin.As part of its efforts to revive growth and better compete against the likes of Amazon and Walmart, Target has ramped up investments in its delivery services and infrastructures and is competing aggressively on prices.As a result, fourth quarter gross margin came in 26.2 per cent, compared with 26.6 per cent in the year ago period.Net income was up nearly 35 per cent at $1.1bn, as Target reaped in the benefit of US tax reforms. Stripping out the one-off tax gains, adjusted net income per share was $1.37, compared to its guidance of between $1.30 and $1.40 and analysts forecasts of $1.38.“Our fourth quarter results demonstrate the power of the significant investments we’ve made in our team and our business throughout 2017,” said chief executive Brian Cornell. “Our team’s outstanding execution of Target’s strategic initiatives during the year delivered strong fourth quarter traffic growth in our stores and digital channels, which drove healthy comparable sales in every one of our five core merchandise categories.”Looking ahead, Target is forecasting like-for-like sales to grow in the
low-single digits this year. Full year adjusted earnings per share is seen to be between $5.15 to $5.45, up from the $4.71 recorded in 2017 and compares to market expectations of $5.21 a share.Target — or Tar-zhay as its devotees call it - has managed to buck the much of the malaise that has dogged the wider retail sector with a focus on its own inhouse brands and cheap chic offerings.The company said it will offer more details on its investment plans for 2018 later this morning. This time last year, Target shocked the market by announcing plans to sacrifice $1bn of profit margin for the 2017 fiscal year to better invest in its business.Shares in Target, up by 31 per cent over the past 12 months, fell 2.4 per cent in pre-market trading.

Titular: Wesfarmers/UK: home truths
Subtitular: As the group ponders a Brexit of its own, better value lies elsewhere
Texto: DIY chain owner, renovate thyself. Wesfarmers is taking A$953m (£544m) in writedowns on Homebase. That is pretty special considering the Australian conglomerate spent only £340m on the UK and Irish DIY retailer. Refreshingly, Wesfarmers has blamed itself — having bungled the integration — rather than Brexit, the go-to scapegoat for local businesses. With Wesfarmers considering a retreat of its own, investors should also seek value elsewhere.Homebase expects to lose £97m in the first half, a quarter more than in the same period last year. The purchase never looked compelling. Bunnings, Wesfarmers’ Aussie DIY store chain, ran at more than eight times the British business’s operating profit margins.Bunnings’ return on capital is the highest in the group. It has benefited from a hot local market for home improvement. A boom in the Aussie housing market has supported demand in recent years. Competitor Masters closed its doors a year ago.The good times may be over. Morgan Stanley analysts point to an 8 per cent decline in the value of the house price index, compared with a year ago. They expect the speed with which new houses are added to slow down. Bunnings Australia accounts for 30 per cent of Wesfarmers’ earnings before interest and taxes, second only to the Coles supermarket unit.Monday’s announcement also zeroed the brand value, goodwill and property of Wesfarmers’ Target unit, an Australian department store chain. As a non-food retailer with mid-range prices it is vulnerable to Amazon, which has recently entered the country. Competition from the group’s own Kmart chain of discount stores, too, has caused problems.Despite a 5 per cent drop in value, shares still trade at 17 times earnings before standard deductions. Investors should consider cheaper competitors with similar growth rates and less exposure to real estate, such as Metcash.

Titular: Target shows signs of life after Amazon
Subtitular: Fund managers have dumped many traditional stores on fears of online competition
Texto: There is an enduring and powerful myth that is repeated unquestioningly by market commentators: everything in the stock market today is staggeringly expensive.As surprising as this may sound to some, this much-peddled notion is not actually true. After a near decade-long bull market there are certain household name US stocks that are trading at similar valuations to where they were during the market nadir of 2009.They are, however, trading there for a reason. Large US retailers have been dumped by fund managers on fears that online competition, most notably from the all-conquering Amazon, will drive many traditional stores out of business. Was this the week when the market finally began to entertain the idea that, contrary to consensus, not all traditional retailers are doomed to extinction?Target shares jumped this week on news that its holiday season trading was stronger than expected, with the company raising its outlook for fourth-quarter and full-year earnings. Yet even after the rally Target shares remain far cheaper than the market, offering a trailing free cash flow yield of more than 12 per cent based on last quarter’s numbers and a forward price to earnings multiple of around 15 times.Yet the analyst expectations on which these forward earnings are based are likely to be too low. The Wall Street consensus remains sceptical of the company’s prospects, which is understandable for a management that has frequently been conservative in managing market expectations. Of the 28 bank analysts who cover the stock only four rank it as a “buy”, while 21 rank it as a “hold”, and three as a “sell”.Target management predicted adjusted earnings per share would be between $4.64 and $4.74 for the year, up from its previous forecast of $4.40 to $4.60 a share. Consensus analyst forecasts after the update still have this coming in at the lower end of that range.Today Target remains a cash generative business generating high teen returns on equity while employing conservative amounts of debt. At these valuations, the market only needs to start tentatively entertaining the idea that stronger retailers will have some place in a post-Amazon world and their shares may move from bargain basement to on-trend.miles.johnson@ft.com

Titular: Target hits the bullseye on holiday trading; raises earnings outlook again
Texto: Target hit the bullseye for investors over the crucial holiday shopping period, triggering a 4 per cent rally in the company’s shares in pre-market trading.The retailer, best known for its cheap chic offerings and stylish celebrity partnerships, raised its fourth quarter and full year earnings guidance on Tuesday after reporting a stronger than expected sales gain for the last two months of the year.Like-for-like sales were up 3.4 per cent as shoppers snapped up everything from toys to pressure cookers and pieces from the company’s new home decor collaboration with Fixer Upper star Joanna Gaines.This, along with the expected bump from US tax reforms, prompted Target to up its earnings outlook once again. It now expects adjusted earnings for the fourth quarter to come in at $1.30 to $1.40 a share, compared to the prior range of $1.05 to $1.25 a share. For the full-year, it is predicting adjusted earnings per share of between $4.64 to $4.74, up from its previous forecast of $4.40 to $4.60 a share.“We are very pleased with our holiday season performance, which reflects the progress we’ve made against our strategy throughout the year,” said Brian Cornell, chairman and chief executive of Target.The company said it sees the strong sales momentum continuing in 2018. It is penciling in a low single digit increase in like for like sales and adjusted earnings per share of between $5.15 to $5.45.Target — or Tar-zhay as its devotees call it — announced last March an audacious plan to sacrifice $1bn of profit margin for the 2017 fiscal year in order better compete against Amazon on the e-commerce front and against Walmart and TJMaxx on the price front.Among the initiatives the Minneapolis-based company has taken include: focusing on higher margin categories such as furniture and kids decor through its own private brands such as Pillowfort and Threshold, as well as lowering prices permanently on a range of basic household items to drive foot traffic to its stores.In a bid to boost its two-day delivery services it has start turning its stores into mini distribution centers. It also snapped up delivery service start-up Shipt for $550m in cash last month.Target said on Tuesday that it expects online sales to grow by more than 25 per cent in 2017.

Titular: Is Target on Amazon’s 2018 wish list?
Texto: With the holiday season out of the way, is Amazon gearing up to do some shopping in 2018? One research firm is predicting that retail chain Target will find its way into the acquisitive e-commerce giant’s cart in the new year.Loup Venture — a tech-focused research and venture capital firm co-founded by a former longtime Piper Jaffray analyst, Gene Munster — has put the idea of an Amazon-Target tie-up on its list of tech predictions for 2018.It may sound like a bold move, but Loup Venture makes the case that there are plenty of synergies to be unwrapped by combining Amazon’s digital retail dominance with Target’s red-and-white themed brick-and-mortar presence.For one, Target has done a good job of tapping into the ever-important “mom” demographic — a group that Target has successfully lured with its product mix ranging from kiddie clothing and cheap-chic home decor to laundry detergent and snacks.Amazon too has taken aim at busy women who control their family purchases, targetting them with discounts and deals through their Prime service and serving up child-friendly video content.“Target’s focus on moms is central to Amazon’s approach to win wallet share”, the firm wrote in a New Year’s Day blog post.The second key factor is Target’s wide-reaching, but manageable, physical store presence, the firm said. Even though Amazon is primarily known for its 24/7 online stores, it has been preparing for a future that blends a primary digital presence with a secondary physical one.To that end, Amazon has recently opened of its first brick-and-mortar book stores, plans to go public with its Amazon Go shops and the purchase of the Whole Foods grocery chain, which added about 470 physical stores to Amazon’s basket, according to Loup.Snapping up Target — with more than 1,800 stores in the US, along with 39 distribution centres — would bring Amazon’s store count to about 2,300, Loup reckons. While substantial, that’s still far less than the more than the nearly 11,600 stores worldwide operated by the US retail heavyweight Walmart.Whether such a combination would encounter antitrust resistance is a tough question. But the firm sees the hypothetical deal as more likely to garner approval than not — its biggest competitor Walmart is expected to rack up $500bn in sales in 2017, a 2.6 per cent year-over-year jump, including about $315bn in US sales.Meanwhile a combined Amazon and Target would reach about $176bn in US revenue, Loup estimated. Among the top-18 US retailers, Walmart would still dominate with 23 per cent share, while an Amazon/Target duo would have just a 13 per cent slice of the pie.And Amazon’s pockets are plenty deep to afford a Target shopping trip, the firm said. It estimated that with a 15 per cent premium, Target’s take-out valuation could run about $51bn — 8 per cent of Amazon’s $564bn market cap.Guessing where Amazon may set its sights next is a favourite parlour game on Wall Street, given that its deals have the potential to move markets dramatically ranging from grocers to delivery companies and appliance makers.“Getting the timing on this is difficult, but seeing the value of the combination is easy”, the firm said.Target shares are up 3.3 per cent on the first trading day of the new year at $67.43, while Amazon shares have gained 1.1 per cent to $1.183.12, with post-holiday optimism buoying retailers of all stripes higher.Photo credit: Reuters

Titular: Target buys Instacart rival for $550m in same-day delivery drive
Texto: Target is heeding to the age-old adage that the best defence is good offense.The Minneapolis-based retailer took a bold step towards strengthening its position in the race against Walmart and Amazon for delivery and e-commerce dominance on Wednesday by snapping up delivery service start-up Shipt for $550m in cash.Like rival Instacart, Alabama-based Shipt runs an “on demand” delivery service that connects users to independent contractors who will drop off an order of groceries at their doorsteps at the push of a button.Target said the acquisition will allow it to ramp up its same-day delivery services — an elusive prize that is widely seen as the key for any company that hopes to take on Amazon in the online retail space.“With Shipt’s network of local shoppers and their current market penetration, we will move from days to hours, dramatically accelerating our ability to bring affordable same-day delivery to guests across the country,” said John Mulligan, executive vice president and chief operating officer for Target.“By the 2018 holiday season, we will be servicing every major market across the country with same-day delivery, and Shipt’s service-oriented approach aligns well with Target’s commitment to delivering an exceptional shopping experience for our guests.”While Target has managed to buck the malaise that has gripped the wider retail sector by focusing on building up its own brand of cheap-chic offerings and investing in making supply-chain logistics more efficient, it still trails Walmart and Amazon when it comes to online sales.Shares in Target, down nearly 15 per cent so far this year, rose as much as 2.2 per cent on news of the deal before paring the gain to just 1.7 per cent.

Titular: Target slides on worries over holiday shopping season
Subtitular: US stocks decline with all three main Wall Street indices in the red
Texto: Target shares briefly slid more than a tenth, on a day of declines for the benchmark S&P 500 after the US retailer offered conservative guidance for the critical fourth-quarter holiday shopping season.Despite stronger than expected third-quarter profits, investors sold down their stakes in the big box retail chain as it stared down deep-pocketed rivals who are expected to increase discounts to lure shoppers and gain market share. Target shares dropped 9.9 per cent to $54.16 by close of trading on Wednesday.The company, which has focused on its own brand of cheap-chic offerings to help drive a sales turnround in recent quarters, said it expected adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter would range from $1.05 to $1.25 a share. That was largely below the median analyst forecast for $1.24 a share.“The pressure that we are anticipating is around digital fulfilment as well as all the work we continue to do around value,” Cathy Smith, the company’s chief financial officer, said on a call with Wall Street analysts.Like-for-like sales — a key industry metric — are forecast to grow as much as 2 per cent in the fourth quarter, buoyed by the company’s investments in store remodels and its ecommerce business.That could translate to full-year same-store sales growth between 0 and 1 per cent, above its earlier expectations.Overall sales rose 1.4 per cent from a year earlier to $16.7bn in the three months to the end of October 28. Profits slid 21 per cent from a year earlier to $480m, or 87 cents a share. Both sales and earnings exceeded analyst expectations.Target announced in March a plan to sacrifice $1bn of profit margin this year to better compete against Amazon on the ecommerce front and against Walmart and TJ Maxx on the price front.Among the initiatives that Target is taking include: focusing on higher margin categories such as furniture and kids decor through its own private brands such as Pillowfort and Threshold, as well as boosting its two-day delivery services by turning its stores into mini distribution centres.The company is also testing next-day home delivery of everyday household staples — from laundry detergent to paper towels — in an attempt to rival Amazon’s Pantry and Walmart’s Jet.com dominance in this area.It has also lowered prices permanently on a range of goods to drive foot traffic to its stores.Analysts with both JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs characterised the fourth-quarter guidance as “conservative”, although the former added that the company’s rising same-store sales were “encouraging”.The slide in Target shares accompanied a broader drop across stock indices. The S&P 500 fell 0.6 per cent to 2,564.62 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average also declined 0.6 per cent to 23,271.28. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite followed the trend and was 0.5 per cent lower at 6,706.21.

Titular: Target shares extend drop to nearly 10% amid margin concerns
Texto: Target failed to hit the bullseye for investors on Wednesday.The Minneapolis-based retailer saw its shares slump nearly 10 per cent in morning trading as its forecast for the upcoming holiday season underwhelmed Wall Street and overshadowed a strong set of results for the third quarter.Best known for its cheap-chic offerings and stylish designer collaborations, Target — or Tar-zhay as its devotees call it — has been slashing prices on household staples and ramping up investments in its delivery and fulfillment centres in order to better compete against rival Amazon’s Pantry and Walmart’s Jet.com.But while the company’s “high-low” strategy of building up higher margin in-house brands, while staying aggressive on prices for basic everyday goods, has helped drive a turnaround in sales, it has come at the expense of margins, as the company warned in March when it unveiled its turnaround plan.Although sales rose 1.4 per cent to $16.7bn, net income fell 21 per cent to $480m during the quarter amid higher costs as a results of these investments. Gross margin rate was 29.7 per cent, compared to 29.8 per cent reported in the prior year period.“The pressure that we are anticipating is around digital fulfillment as well as all the work we continue to do around value, and we’re offsetting that with cost savings continuing into the fourth quarter,” said Cathy Smith, chief financial officer, during a call with analysts.The focus on margins has been heightened by concerns that Target would need to step discounts and promotions to compete against deep-pocketed rivals Amazon and Walmart ahead of the critical holiday shopping season.These jitters were not assuaged by Target’s fourth-quarter earnings forecast. Adjusted earnings are expected come in between $1.05 to $1.25 a share for the fourth quarter, compared to average consensus forecast of $1.24 a share.“The reaction in TGT shares is a little surprising today even if buy-side expectations were a little higher than the print,” said Daniel Binder, analyst at Jefferies. “We think the upbeat earnings call had a balance of a conservative outlook and confidence in the turnaround initiatives, but after a large beat to the low end of Q3 EPS guidance, we think investors were hoping to see more on the FY18 revision.”Still, Target issued a confident outlook for its parts.“While the fourth quarter is always intensely competitive, we are entering this holiday season with lots of confidence,” said chief executive Brian Cornell. “And while it’s still very early we’ve been encouraged with the guest response to launch of Hearth and Hand as well as last week’s release of the Target exclusive version Taylor Swift’s new album, Reputation. While the bulk of the season is still ahead of us, we are very happy to see how these early efforts have set the tone for the season.”Shares in Target are down 9.4 per cent in midday trading taking its year-to-date losses to nearly 25 per cent.

Titular: Target lifts guidance as private brands drive sales growth
Texto: Target continued to buck the wider malaise in the US retail sector, with the retailer raising its full year sales and earnings outlook after posting third quarter results that topped analysts’ expectations.However, shares slid in pre-market trading on Wednesday amid jitters over how it would fare against the likes of Amazon and Walmart ahead of the all-important shopping season.The company, whose focus on its own-brand of cheap-chic offerings has helped drive a sales turnaround in recent quarters, said it now expects earnings per share from continuing operations for 2017 to come in at between $4.38 to $4.58, up from the $4.35 to $4.55 range it gave just three months ago.Like-for-like sales – a key industry metric – are forecast to grow as much as one per cent, as investments in store remodeling, exclusive in house brands and e-commerce lure more shoppers to its stores and boost sales. It had previously predicted the metric to be flat, plus or minus 1 per cent.The higher guidance comes as Target reported a 0.9 per cent rise in like-for-like sales in the three months to end of October, more than twice the 0.4 per cent increase that the market had forecast. Overall sales rose 1.4 per cent to $16.7bn, ahead of analysts’ estimate for $16.6bn. Net income of $480m, or 87 cents per diluted share, also exceed expectations of $468m, or 86 cents a share.“We’re very pleased with Target’s third quarter performance,” said Brian Cornell, chief executive. “The investments we’re making in our business will help Target drive long-term success and ensure we’re well positioned to deliver for guests in the all-important holiday season.”Target announced in March an audacious plan to sacrifice $1bn of profit margin this year in order better compete against Amazon on the e-commerce front and against Walmart and TJMaxx on the price front.Among the initiatives that Target is taking include: focusing on higher margin categories such as furniture and kids decor through its own private brands such as Pillowfort and Threshold, as well as boosting its two-day delivery services by turning its stores into mini distribution centers. The company is also testing next-day home delivery of everyday household staples — from laundry detergent to paper towels — in an attempt to rival Amazon’s Pantry and Walmart’s Jet.com dominance in this area. It has also lowered prices permanently on a range of goods to drive foot traffic to its stores.And despite the steady sales gain and the company’s upbeat comments for the key holiday period, investors remained wary over the impact that this would have on profit margins. The retailer’s forecast for adjusted earnings to come in a between $1.05 to $1.25 a share for the fourth quarter failed to impress. Average consensus forecast was for $1.24 a share.Shares in Target fell 5.3 per cent in pre-market trading.“Q3 results for Target reflect the impact of its short-term investments for long-term benefit, with margins softening slightly as a result of Target’s tactical price investments, as well as the persistent market share battles with Amazon and Walmart in multiple categories, though we believe margin erosion is being mitigated to an extent by private and exclusive brands, which are resonating with shoppers,” said Charlie O’Shea, lead retail analysts at Moody’s.Results from US retailers have been mixed so far this earnings season. Margins, inventory management and comments on the upcoming holiday trading season have drawn closer investor scrutiny this quarter. Traditional underperformers such as Macy’s saw shares gain nearly 11 per cent last Thursday after the market overlooked a 11th straight quarter of like-for-like sales decline to cheer the rise in the company’s gross profit margin. JC Penney – another retailer that has fared poorly – also saw its shares rise after it beat expectations that were lowered only weeks ago.By contrast, TJX Companies, the parent of off price discount chains TJ Maxx and Marshalls, and one of the more resilient retailers, was punished by investors after posting a rare miss in comparable sales and revenues.Likewise, Kohl’s received little love from the market after its margins fell short of expectations. The modest gain came despite the department store operator eking out its first like-for-like sales rise in nearly two years.(Photo: AP)

Titular: Target boosts holiday hiring in bet turnround momentum will continue
Texto: Target said on Wednesday that it planned to hire more than 100,000 workers for the holiday season, a sharp jump from the 70,000 it hired last year and underscores the retailer’s confidence for the busiest shopping period of the year despite wider industry woes.The Minneapolis-based group said it planned to add about 100,000 temporary staff members to help stock shelves, man cash registers and assist customers across its 1,816 stores in the US. An additional 4,500 workers will also be hired to work at its distribution centers in anticipation of more online orders.The move suggests Target is confident that the momentum that it has seen in its sales turnround in the first six months of the year will continue into the second half.Shares in Target rose nearly 3 per cent to $59.58 on the news. The stock has gained 8 per cent over the past six months, joining rival big box chain Walmart in outperforming beleaguered department store operators Macy’s (down 28 per cent) and Sears (down 15 per cent).The holiday shopping season typically kicks off on Black Friday, or the day after Thanksgiving and continues into early January. The period is by far the most important one for the retailers with many generating as much as a third of their sales during this two month stretch.“Target has made significant investments in our business throughout 2017, and our commitment to hire 100,000 team members for the holidays will make shopping at Target even easier and more fun during one of the busiest times of the year,” said Janna Potts, chief stores officer.

Titular: Target ups ante on price wars, sends retail stocks lower
Texto: Target has upped the ante in the ongoing retail price war, saying on Friday that it has slashed prices on “thousands of items” in a bid to win market shares and boost foot traffic amid a tough trading environment.But the news, coming on the heels of Amazon’s move to cut prices on a wide range of household staples at Whole Foods last week, is likely to fan concerns in the market that the intensifying discounting would only further erode profit margins at the country’s major retailers.Indeed, the news prompted shares in Target to drop 2 per cent and dragged other retailers lower. Costco, Walmart and Dollar General — all purveyors of basic goods — are down 1.4 per cent, 1.5 per cent and 1.2 per cent, respectively.Supermarkets have had a rough 2017 so far. Even before Amazon made public its interest in Whole Foods in June, grocers were reeling from falling food prices and the arrival of German discount grocers Lidl and Aldi in the US.The pain in the sector was underscored by Kroger, which reported a 30 basis points drop in gross margin during the second quarter earlier this morning, as it too had to ramp up promotions and discounts to compete for US retail dollars.Target had made no secret of its plans to cut prices on basic household goods. Earlier this March, the Minneapolis-based group unveiled an audacious plan to sacrifice $1bn of profit margin this year in order better compete against Amazon on e-commerce and against Walmart and TJMaxx on price.It’s betting that by lowering prices on everyday items like cereal and paper towels, it will be able to lure in shoppers and tempt them to buy higher margin products — namely its in-house brands of furniture, home decor and clothing.Its plan appear to be yielding dividends. In its most recent quarter, Target swung back to sales growth and lifted its full year earnings guidance. In contrast to other retailers, the company’s gross margin has also held up well, dipping to 30.5 per cent in the second quarter, from 30.9 per cent a year earlier.

Titular: Week in Review, August 19
Subtitular: US retailers, Air Berlin, China Unicom, accountants and Akzo Nobel in the news
Texto: A round up of some of the week’s most significant corporate events and news stories.Mixed results for US chains battling rise of online rivalsA host of US retail companies reported earnings this week, revealing patchy but less dire results than analysts had forecast, as heavy investments by big box retailers appeared to pay off, writes Anna Nicolaou.The US retail sector is experiencing huge upheaval, as online shopping and in particular ecommerce behemoth Amazon have upended traditional business models, and consumer tastes evolve.Those best equipped to withstand the disruption have been companies with deep pockets, such as Walmart, which reported that ecommerce revenues rose 60 per cent in the second quarter. Comparable sales rose 1.8 per cent, the 12th consecutive quarterly rise.Target, whose cheap-chic offerings have garnered a loyal middle-class following, also offered positive news, reporting a 1.3 per cent rise in comparable sales, its first gain in five quarters. The growth follows Target’s announcement in March of a turnround plan to sacrifice $1bn of profit margin this year in order to compete better against Amazon online.Urban Outfitters, the teen-focused apparel company. reported adjusted earnings per share of 45 cents, topping the consensus for 36 cents and sending shares soaring 16 per cent as a sign of life for stores struggling with declining mall traffic.Other retailers fared worse, however. Dick’s Sporting Goods, the Pittsburgh-based sports chain, sharply lowered its earnings and sales outlook on Tuesday, while Coach also warned its sales in this fiscal year could come in below Wall Street expectations, sending shares tumbling.Ryanair fury as Lufthansa sizes up Air Berlin assetsAir Berlin became the second large European airline to go bankrupt this summer after it was forced to file for insolvency on Tuesday when its biggest shareholder pulled its funding, writes Tanya Powley.Germany’s second-largest carrier was saved from a full collapse after Berlin stepped in with a €150m loan to keep the airline flying through the busy summer months while it negotiated the sale of parts of the business to Lufthansa and one other airline.The move was triggered when Etihad, the Abu Dhabi-based airline that owns 29 per cent of Air Berlin, decided not to pump in any more money after providing a series of cash injections over the past six years to keep it afloat.Air Berlin’s insolvency comes just four months after Alitalia, the Italian carrier, entered administration after its employees rejected a restructuring plan and Etihad, which also owns a significant stake in Alitalia, said it would provide no more funding.Air Berlin has been under pressure after racking up losses of about €2bn over the past six years. The situation has worsened as Etihad has faced its own challenges, forcing it to unravel its strategy of buying minority stakes in airlines to drive traffic to its hub in the Gulf. Etihad made losses of $1.9bn in 2016.Air Berlin’s collapse has sparked a fierce battle over the rights to prime German take-off and landing slots, with Ryanair, Europe’s biggest low-cost airline, branding a state bailout of the airline as a “conspiracy” to protect national carrier Lufthansa.China Unicom in line for $11.7bn of private capitalChina Unicom, the country’s second-largest mobile operator, will receive a $11.7bn capital injection from some of China’s biggest ecommerce and internet groups, including Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu, writes Don Weinland in Hong Kong.The investment is the latest step in the government’s efforts to pump private capital into declining state-controlled businesses.Ten groups will buy a total of 35.19 per cent of Unicom’s Shanghai-listed unit. Of this, Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu and one other group, JD.com, will hold a combined 12.6 per cent.State-backed companies will also invest. China’s biggest life insurance company China Life, as well as a government-controlled fund that invests in companies undergoing reform, will take large stakes.China Life will buy by far the biggest stake of any single group, at 10 per cent. Unicom’s parent company will maintain a 36.67 per cent holding.Tencent president Martin Lau described the ownership reform scheme as “a very momentous step in the development of the country”.The round of investment had been anticipated for months and was announced on Wednesday.So-called “mixed-ownership reform” — the introduction of private capital into state groups — has been touted by Xi Jinping, leader of China’s communist party, as a means of revitalising state groups.However, industry watchers say private investment in state groups has produced few, if any, results over the past two decades.Top management at state companies is still chosen by government agencies and bears little connection to commercial performance, experts say.KPMG and PwC fined over substandard external auditsUS and UK regulators shone a light on poor practice at accountancy firms this week, slapping both KPMG and PwC with hefty fines for audit failures, writes Hannah Murphy. KPMG was on Tuesday hit with a fine of more than $6.2m by the US Securities and Exchanges Commission over its audit of oil and gas company Miller Energy in 2011. Miller had overvalued certain assets by more than 100 times and last year settled accounting fraud charges with the SEC.A day later, PwC was fined £5.1m by the Financial Reporting Council — the largest ever penalty issued by the UK’s accounting watchdog — for “extensive misconduct” relating to the audit of a smaller consultancy firm RSM Tenon. PwC admitted to five separate instances of misconduct in its 2011 audit of the company, which was later forced to restate its accounts for that year after discovering “significant errors”.RSM Tenon was put into administration in 2013 after building up major debts and sold to rival Baker Tilly. Regulators are keen to improve the quality of external audits. So far this year, the FRC has launched investigations into the audit of UK companies including Rolls-Royce, BT and Mitie — which involve KPMG, PwC and Deloitte respectively.Akzo Nobel ends bitter spat with largest shareholderAkzo Nobel, the Dutch paintmaker behind the Dulux brand, agreed a truce with the activist investor Elliott Advisors following a bitter feud over the company’s rejection of a €27bn takeover offer, writes Michael Pooler.The Amsterdam-based group announced an agreement with its largest shareholder, which holds a 9.5 per cent stake in Akzo and for months has berated its management and brought legal challenges against the company.A dispute blew up earlier this year over the Akzo’s refusal to engage in buyout talks with its US rival PPG Industries. A combination would have created a dominant player in the $130bn global paints and coatings market.Under the peace deal, both parties will suspend all ongoing litigation for at least three months. Elliott has unsuccessfully pursued a legal case to force the removal of Akzo’s chairman, Antony Burgmans, who was seen an obstacle to a deal with PPG and is retiring next year.For its part, Akzo nominated two new board members and said it intended to nominate a third, in consultation with its major shareholders.In exchange Elliott Advisors, which is the UK arm of the New York-based hedge fund, will back the appointment of a new chief executive. Thierry Vanlancker is taking over from Ton Büchner, who resigned last month due to health reasons.The accord also included “alignment” on Akzo’s plan to split itself into two separate entities. As part of its defence against PPG, Akzo pledged to separate its speciality chemicals division, leaving a core business focused on paints and coatings.Elliott, which led a band of dissenting shareholders who publicly criticised the Dutch company’s handling of the PPG episode, said it “look[ed] forward to building upon the recent constructive dialogue”.This week Elliott also revealed it had increased its stake in BHP Billiton, with a 5 per cent cash position in the group’s London-listed shares. Elliott has alleged the miner has underperformed its peers, needs to return more cash to shareholders and exit its US shale operations.

Titular: Target lifts full-year guidance as turnaround efforts gather steam
