This month it removed its chief executive, Gregg Steinhafel, and on Tuesday replaced the head of its Canadian business, which has lost $1.5bn since the first stores opened there last year.“We are not where we need to be,” John Mulligan, interim chief executive, said.Target said it would spend more this year to improve US sales, fix Canadian operations and catch up with rivals in the increasingly important arena of digital sales, which will eat into full-year profit. Adjusted earnings are expected of $3.60-$3.90 a share, down from a previous estimate of $3.85-$4.15 a share.That excludes any expenses related to the cyber attack, the company said, adding that it was “unable to estimate future expenses related to the data breach”. Mr Mulligan said the company would not know the full extent of its liabilities until the third quarter of this year.Target is also holding off on share buybacks until the second half of the year at least, he added.The company is facing numerous class action lawsuits over the breach and executives have had to testify before Congress. The incident racked up $18m in net expenses in the first quarter, as $26m in total costs were offset somewhat by insurance.Target shares rose 1 per cent to $57.20 on Wednesday in New York. The stock has dropped 9.5 per cent this year.Although the massive data breach, which could have exposed the personal and credit card data of up to a third of the US population, created a public spectacle out of Target, the retailer was already battling on multiple fronts.Since the downturn, it has struggled to boost US store traffic as customers maintained a tight hold on their purse strings or opted to shop at online rivals.Even as Target slashed prices to draw in customers – narrowing its gross margins to below 30 per cent – US same-store sales fell 0.3 per cent in the first quarter. The number of transactions dropped 2.3 per cent but its average ticket price rose 2.1 per cent as shoppers bought more expensive items.Brian Sozzi, chief equities strategist at Belus Capital Advisors, said the traffic decline began before the November data breach. “Weak store visits suggest newly incoming/promoted Target executives must consider further scaling down the US store base,” he said.While the company is forecasting 2 per cent comparable sales growth in the US this year, Mr Mulligan acknowledged that lifting traffic would be “very difficult”.The company is aiming to get more customers shopping online, which accounts for about 2.5 per cent of sales. It said it had success in allowing customers to order online and pick up items in stores. A pilot programme that offers same-day delivery of items from stores will be expanded to Boston, Minneapolis and Miami in June.In Canada, losses before interest and taxes widened to $211m from $205m a year ago, while sales grew to $393m from $86m last year, when Target opened its first 24 stores in the country.That quickly grew to 127 stores but the company’s first international foray turned into a bungled attempt that exposed the company to ridicule as shoppers turned away from merchandise seen as too expensive and not catering to local tastes.Additional reporting by Anjli Ravalshannon.bond@ft.comTwitter: @shannonpareil

Titular: Target chief steps down after data breach
Texto: Gregg Steinhafel, Target’s chief executive, has resigned from the US retailer after a disastrous cybersecurity breach that ruined its festive shopping season at the end of last year.Analysts said Mr Steinhafel’s departure reflected board displeasure with the handling of the cyberattack and the under-investment that led to it, as well as broader worries that Target was losing its relevance in the ecommerce era.The Minneapolis-based retailer had been criticised for reacting too slowly to a data breach that lasted nearly three weeks, and Mr Steinhafel’s resignation comes more than five months after it began. The attack started in late November 2013 but was not announced until December 19.The retailer said on Monday that Mr Steinhafel, who has been with the company for 35 years, would be replaced temporarily by John Mulligan, its chief financial officer. In March, the group announced the resignation of its chief information officer.Target grew to become the fifth-biggest US retailer with annual revenue of $72bn thanks to its focus on “cheap chic”, stylish clothes and household goods at affordable prices. But in recent years it has struggled to keep the brand fresh.Mr Steinhafel also launched an expansion into Canada last year, but the effort sapped profits and ran into trouble as Target’s products did not suit local tastes.The cyber breach made things worse: Target’s like-for-like sales fell 2.5 per cent in the quarter to the end of January as wary customers stayed away from the chain.In one of the worst data breaches the retail sector has seen, cyber criminals infected Target’s payment systems with malicious software, stealing the personal data of 70m people and the credit and debit card details of at least 40m.Faye Landes, analyst at Cowen & Co, said in a research note: “We take [Mr Steinhafel’s departure] as a sign that [Target’s] many problems are deep-seated, and we now fear that the company will be even more rudderless.“Presumably the board was not pleased with Steinhafel’s performance, and we think that it is fair to assume that current business trends are not particularly good.” She said the board might also want to see better merchandise on the shelves.David Schick, analyst at Stifel Nicolaus, said Target was in a tougher spot than many of its peers because the customers it traditionally relied on were doing more online shopping than others.“[Target] continues to face the issue of the younger, more affluent, more urban discount shopper simply not wanting to go to stores in the same way as their predecessors,” he said.Target said it was searching for a permanent replacement for Mr Steinhafel and had hired the headhunting group Korn Ferry.Last week it named long-time government adviser Bob DeRodes as its new chief information officer, replacing Beth Jacob.The retailer also said last week that it was working with MasterCard to roll out credit and debit cards equipped with chips after criticism that its current swipe technology was not secure enough.

Titular: AB Foods: UK retailers in the US
Subtitular: Given history of British retail failures in the US, why is Primark going to Boston?
Texto: At least it will be easy for bargain hunters to find. Primark’s decision to locate its first US outlet on the site of Filene’s – a now-closed Boston department store famous for its bargain basement – is historically poignant if nothing else. The UK-based discount clothes chain will feel at home when it moves in next year.In a triumph of hope over experience, investors cheered the news. Shares in Primark owner Associated British Foods rose 8 per cent. UK retailers – most recently Tesco – have a mostly dismal record in the US. Primark will be taking on the likes of TJ Maxx (located just down the street from Filene’s) and Target. Market valuations are optimistic for Primark. On 27 times forecast earnings, AB Foods shares are at a premium to both rivals: TJX Companies is on 17, and Target 13.But it is not hard to see why AB Foods is so keen to take a risk in the US. Primark is the biggest and most exciting part of the group. Its profits grew 26 per cent in the first half of the current fiscal year and it produced a return on capital of 32 per cent. Other businesses in the conglomerate are duller. First-half profits in sugar fell by almost two-thirds as prices fell.And what really drives Primark is expansion. Same-store sales grew 4 per cent in the first half – pretty good, although less healthy than the 7 per cent in the same period last year. To keep double digit growth going it needs to keep building. Primark has 160 stores in the UK and 70 in continental Europe. The US is the next logical step, although sticking with European expansion alone would have been lower risk. Still, Primark will not bet the farm in the US. Net debt stands at £827m, which is less than 0.5 times earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation. US expansion costing, say, £100m to £200m is – much like its products – easily affordable.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Target’s IT chief resigns in wake of data breach
Texto: Target has announced the resignation of its chief information officer and an overhaul of its information security and compliance practices, in the wake of a massive cyber security attack on the US retailer during the holiday season.Gregg Steinhafel, chief executive, said the Minessotta-based discount stores group will conduct an external search for an interim replacement for Beth Jacob to help the company through the transformation.“While we are still in the process of an ongoing investigation, we recognise that the information security environment is evolving rapidly,” he said on Wednesday.Ms Jacob, who was appointed to the role in 2008, oversaw Target’s computer systems. She is the first high-profile executive to leave the company since the data breach.Target has said personal data of 70m people and the credit and debit card details of at least 40m were stolen between November 27 and December 15, after malicious software was deployed against the retailer’s payment systems.Mr Steinhafel said the company will also begin an external search for a chief compliance officer and plans to “elevate” the new role of the chief information security officer, seeking an external candidate for that position, too.Last week, Target reported that its fourth-quarter net income almost halved year-on-year, to $520m, and revenues fell 5.3 per cent, to $21.5bn, as the data theft deterred customers.Although Target has since experienced a small rebound in sales, it warned last week that the cyber attack may still have a “material adverse effect” on this year’s earnings.Hacking-related costs have so far totalled $61m, although Target said it expects all except for $17m to be covered by insurance.In addition, Target is investing $100m in cards equipped with chips, which analysts have said are less prone to hacking than the traditional magnetic stripe cards that are still commonly used in the US. It is also offering free credit monitoring for a year to all Target customers.The company hired Promontory Financial Group in January to help re-evaluate its technology and processes, as part of the process to restore trust in its security procedures.Faye Landes, analyst at Cowen & Co, said any measures that the new executives take “will be costly” for the retailer, particularly as it “appears likely that Target has been underinvesting in IT”.She added: “We suspect that [Ms Jacob’s] replacement will not be someone who tells the press that it is a misconception that ‘the most important skill set of a CIO is that of a techie’,” referring to a 2012 interview given by Ms Jacob.Separately, cosmetics chain Sally Beauty said on Wedesday it was the latest victim of a breach targeting their payment systems. Although the company had “detected an attempted intrusion” it said there was “no reason to believe there has been any loss of credit card or consumer data”.

Titular: Abercrombie in vogue with investors
Texto: Abercrombie & Fitch rallied 9 per cent after the company’s fourth-quarter profit topped expectations and the retailer said it would accelerate a share buyback programme.The fashion retailer, which owns the Hollister chain as well as its namesake brand, said profits more than halved in the period, falling to $66.1m, or 85 cents per diluted share.When adjusting for charges, including the closing of its Gilly Hicks lingerie brand and its cost-cutting programme, Abercrombie said it earned $1.34 per share, ahead of Wall Street forecasts.Same-store sales declined 8 per cent in the three months to February, slightly better than expectations of an 8.8 per cent dip.That, coupled with the announcement of an accelerated $150m share buyback programme, was enough to send its shares 11.2 per cent higher to $40.04.Net sales in the fourth quarter fell 11 per cent from a year earlier to $1.3bn.Abercrombie expects same-store sales at its stores to decline by a “high-single digit” per cent over the remainder of the year, although overall sales are to be buoyed by a 20 per cent increase in online orders.The company said margins were pressured as it increased promotional activity in its stores to ratchet up demand.“We are in a different environment in terms of price resistance,” chief executive Michael Jeffries said on a call with analysts. “Clearly, it’s an old axiomatic statement that good fashion doesn’t have a price attached to it but today it does.”Barnes & Noble shares rose 4.2 per cent to $18.47 after the US bookseller said it swung to a third-quarter profit of $63.2m, or 86 cents per diluted share, as the company continued to cut expenses in its Nook e-reader business.Sales fell 10 per cent to $2bn, roughly in line with analyst expectations.Chief executive Michael Huseby said the company benefited from a strong book catalogue during the quarter as well as improved marketing initiatives.Barnes & Noble reaffirmed its full-year guidance, which forecasts retail same-store sales to decline by a high single-digit per cent.The company has refocused itself around its core business of selling books in brick-and-mortar retail stores and away from the Nook digital business, which includes ebooks, ereaders and tablet computers.Nook sales have languished against well-capitalised rivals from Samsung and Apple.Target, the US retailer that has struggled since it disclosed hackers gained access to shopper information, rose 7 per cent on Wednesday to $60.49 after the company’s chief executive said “sales trends have improved in recent weeks”.Profits for the quarter, which runs to February 1, fell 46 per cent from a year earlier to $520m, or 81 cents a share. Revenue edged 5 per cent lower to $21.5bn.First Solar was among the biggest declining stocks on the benchmark S&P 500, falling 9.1 per cent to $52.74 after the company said profits fell 58 per cent in the fourth quarter.The company said profits fell to $65.2m, or 64 cents per share, as sales fell 29 per cent to $768m.First Solar said the results included asset impairments and restructuring charges after market close on Tuesday.First Solar has had difficulty filling its order book, selling slightly more solar panels than it was able to manufacture over the course of the year.“We continue to see lack of upside in First Solar’s utility scale model given checks which suggest a challenging US growth outlook for large-scale utility projects [and] mixed, early results in new growth markets,” Goldman Sachs analyst Brian Lee said.Overall, US equities rose moderately as better than expected new home sales counterbalanced recent weak figures on the country’s housing market.The S&P 500 was flat at 1,845.16 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average nudged up 0.1 per cent to 16,198.41. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite index was up 0.1 per cent to 4,292.06.

Titular: Target earnings top shrunken expectations
Texto: Target Corp’s holiday quarter earnings beat expectations, sending shares higher, even as the US discount retailer dealt with the fallout from a cyber security attack in its domestic market and weak store traffic in Canada.Shares rose 7.5 per cent to $60.74 by midday New York trading on Wednesday.Before the earnings release investors had slashed forecasts for the company that had lost more than $3.5bn in market value since it disclosed in December that 40m shoppers’ credit and debit card records and 70m people’s personal data had been compromised.Gregg Steinhafel, chief executive, said the company’s spare-no-expense response to the crisis might even be paying off. Target has boosted its discounts and offered a year of free credit card monitoring to all its shoppers.“We will continue to work tirelessly to win back the confidence of our guests and deliver irresistible merchandise and offers, and we are encouraged that sales trends have improved in recent weeks,” he said.Although net income almost halved to $520m, or 81 cents a share, from $961m, or $1.47, a year earlier, the Minneapolis-based company exceeded analysts’ reduced expectations of 79 cents.Sales declined 5.3 per cent to $21.5bn in the three months to February 1, but the fall was in line with Wall Street’s lowered forecasts.The company said it expected earnings a share for the current quarter to range from 60 cents to 75 cents. For the full year, Target forecasts earnings a share to range between $3.85 and $4.15. Analysts expect earnings about the $4 mark.Target incurred $61m in expenses related to the breach during the quarter, but those costs were offset by a $44m insurance payment, bringing down the net cost to the retailer to $17m.Industry watchers have sought to gauge the longer-term impact of the incident. Although the company said it expected to absorb any near-term shocks, it was not able to estimate future expenses related to the data breach, beyond saying that these could have a “material adverse effect” on 2014 earnings.Potential costs include those tied to reissuing cards, lawsuits, federal investigations and enforcement proceedings and consulting feesPotential costs include those tied to reissuing cards, lawsuits, federal investigations and enforcement proceedings, legal expenses, investigative and consulting fees, and capital investments.Target is investing $100m in cards equipped with chips, which analysts have said are less prone to hacking than the traditional magnetic stripe cards commonly used in the US.Target has struggled with uneven sales since the financial downturn as its middle-income shoppers are still keeping a tight rein on spending. Although sales before the data breach were in line with expectations, a drop in traffic to its stores in the weeks after damped quarterly numbers. Harsh east coast winter weather also added to pressures.Efforts to clear excess inventory and control costs helped the retailer’s gross margins decline to 27.6 per cent in the quarter, compared with 27.8 per cent in 2012. The company expects to cut $1bn in spending by 2015.Meanwhile Target’s Canada business underwhelmed in its performance as costs continued to increase and sales lagged behind, resulting in a widening fourth quarter operating loss of $329m, from $148m the year before. Canadian customers have stayed away as merchandise has not met local tastes and prices have been higher than the group’s US stores.

Titular: Target shrugs off Canada woes
Texto: Target is pushing ahead with its expansion into Canada, despite soaring costs and a cyber hacking crisis in the US discount retailer’s home market.Target opened 124 stores across 10 provinces last year and now seeks to add another nine locations in Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba, Alberta and British Columbia, the company said on Wednesday.But the Minnesota-based group’s much-hyped first major international foray, on which it said it would spend just over $4bn in 2013, has had a troubled start, as costs escalated and sales remained weak.“Target has failed miserably in Canada,” said Brian Sozzi, chief equity strategist at Belus Capital Advisors. “They have invested a lot more than expected in the business, but the main problem is they didn’t tailor stores to the market.”Canadian customers have stayed away as merchandise has not met local tastes, analysts said. Prices at Target – renowned for bringing cheap chic to low-price retail – are also too high. Near-empty shelves have been another criticism as a result of restocking problems.This month Target said lacklustre sales at its Canadian stores would have a bigger impact on fourth-quarter results than it had initially thought as it slashed prices to clear out unsold goods, hurting gross margins.Department store Sears has also been hampered by poor Canada sales, warning it faces a hefty loss for the fourth quarter. Sears Canada has been winding down operations at several stores and selling off merchandise at discounted rates.For Target, the data breach in which the credit card details and personal data of tens of millions of customers were stolen has only complicated efforts to control spending. Industry watchers have said Target’s costs are set to increase as a result of litigation, upgraded technology, fraud reimbursement and card reissuance.Target, which has 361,000 employees, announced 475 job cuts last week and said it would eliminate 700 posts in its Minneapolis headquarters, in the largest round of corporate job cuts since 2009. It also said it would no longer offer health insurance for part-time employees.“Target is facing battles on many fronts. The main challenge for them is getting the store traffic back in the US where it has more than 1,700 stores,” said Michael Monatani, analyst at ISI Group.“As for Canada, Target has to learn from the mistakes of the last year and correct problems over time, which I’m confident it will do. The company is in a crisis situation and needs loyal customers.”Target shares have fallen almost 15 per cent since mid-November to $57.08.Despite its struggles, the retailer, which has eyed the Canadian market for more than a decade, says it remains committed to its push across the border.Tony Fisher, Target Canada president, said: “As we head into 2014, we will continue to enhance the guest experience at all stores, while continuing to expand our presence in new Canadian neighbourhoods.”

Titular: US retailers unite to boost defences against cyber criminals
Texto: US big box retailers are joining forces to strengthen their defences against cyber criminals following data breaches that have compromised tens of millions of shoppers.The Retail Industry Leaders Association (RILA), a trade group for the country’s largest retailers, said on Monday it had launched an initiative to counter potential cyber threats and promote additional safeguards for personal data.“Retailers place extremely high priority on data security and invest tremendous resources to prevent attacks, but cyber criminals are persistent and their methods of attack are increasingly sophisticated,” said RILA president Sandy Kennedy.Target disclosed that personal data from more than 70m people and the credit card details of at least 40m had been stolen between November 27 and December 15 after malicious software was deployed against the retailer.Department store Neiman Marcus said 2,400 customer credit cards might have been used fraudulently and the data of approximately 1.1m could have been compromised. Michaels Companies, the arts and crafts retailer, said it too was investigating a possible security breach on its payment card network.“By working together with public-private sector stakeholders, our ability to develop innovative solutions and anticipate threats will grow, enhancing our collective security,” Ms Kennedy added.The group will form a council of senior retail executives to enable information sharing about potential threats. It will also lobby lawmakers to develop federal legislation on data security breach notification.Retailers are trying to do everything they possibly can, but ultimately it is a game of cat and mouse with one side trying to outsmart the otherLike other industry watchers, RILA is calling for the elimination of credit and debit cards that use magnetic stripe technology, which are outdated and easily exploitable. It wants chip-based smart cards and universal PIN security to be adopted instead.RILA also seeks to forge closer relationships with banks, credit card processing companies and other members of the payment cycle, as well as improve communication with consumers on how their personal data are used.But security experts say retailers have little chance of providing a completely secure payment system for customers against sophisticated cyber thieves. Corporate security teams have faced great difficulty in tracking and eradicating such malware in commercial settings, as hackers tend to sell on the software via multi-layered underground forums.“Retailers are trying to do everything they possibly can, but ultimately it is a game of cat and mouse with one side trying to outsmart the other,” said Richard Bortnick, a lawyer who advises companies about cyber security risks. “There is only so much a retailer can prepare for the worse case scenario.”

Titular: FBI warns retailers of more cyber attacks
Texto: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has warned US retailers they may face further cyber attacks after detecting 20 hacking cases in the past year that used the same malicious software that was deployed against Target over the Thanksgiving shopping season.The agency cautioned retailers about the risks posed by “memory-parsing” malware that can compromise card swiping machines and other point of sales systems, the FBI confirmed on Thursday.“We believe POS malware crime will continue to grow over the near term, despite law enforcement and security firms’ actions to mitigate it,” the January 17 report entitled “Recent Cyber Intrusion Events Directed Toward Retail Firms” said.News of the three-page confidential document, first reported by Reuters, came after retailer Target disclosed that personal data from more than 70m people and the credit card details of at least 40m had been stolen between November 27 and December 15. Department store Neiman Marcus has also said 2,400 customer credit cards may have been used fraudulently and the data of approximately 1.1m may have been compromised.“The accessibility of the malware on underground forums, the affordability of the software and the huge potential profits to be made from retail POS systems in the US make this type of financially motivated cyber crime attractive to a wide range of actors,” the FBI added.IntelCrawler, the Los Angeles-based cyber security group, last week said malware had been deployed against at least six other US retailers. Meanwhile, the Online Trust Alliance, a non-profit group, estimates that more than 740m records were exposed in 2013, making it the worst year for data breaches to date.The FBI report highlighted the difficulties corporate security teams face in tracking and eradicating such malware in commercial settings, particularly as hackers sell on the software via multi-layered underground forums. One type of malware has been offered for as much as $6,000, the FBI said.Small- and medium-sized local and regional businesses, where losses ranged from tens of thousands of dollars to millions of dollars, have been the main targets of POS malware cases the FBI had investigated.The agency examines cyber crime cases alongside the Secret Service, which is investigating the data breaches at Target and Neiman Marcus. A Secret Service spokesperson declined to comment.Separately, Target said that John Mulligan, its chief financial officer, will testify before the US Senate Judiciary Committee on February 4 about the data breach. The news capped a turbulent week for the US retailer, which also announced it would cut 475 jobs from its global workforce.

Titular: Target was not sole cyber attack victim
Texto: The malware used to steal tens of millions of customer credit-card details from Target over Thanksgiving has been deployed against at least six other US retailers, according to a cyber security group.Researchers from IntelCrawler, a Los Angeles-based company, said that they have traced the attack back to a 17-year-old hacker who created malware called BlackPOS.Andrew Komarov, chief executive of IntelCrawler, said that six other point-of-sales systems had been compromised by the same malware, short for malicious software, two in LA and the rest in other US cities.“Most of the victims are department stores. More BlackPOS infections, as well as new breaches, could appear very soon; retailers and the security community should be prepared for them,” he said.Cyber security companies have been known to issue reports on new attacks to raise their company profile. The Financial Times was unable independently to verify the attacks reported by IntelCrawler.IntelCrawler is not the first cyber security company that has warned that more retailers were likely to be attacked using the same methods deployed in the Target attack. But until now no one has claimed to have traced exactly how many and where the retailers are.Retailers have become more vulnerable over the past year, according to Bitsight, which tracks where cyber attacks originate to compile a credit rating-like score for companies.Bitsight said that 40 per cent of the Fortune 200 retailers, excluding supermarkets, had a worse score than Target on its index. In the six weeks from the beginning of November, it found more than a thousand different infections from corporate networks at 139 US retailers.As online threats race up national security agendas and governments look at ways of protecting their national infrastructures a cyber arms race is causing concern to the developed worldTarget admitted last week that it had lost data from more than 70m customers stolen in the Thanksgiving cyber attack, as well as reporting last month that at least 40m credit-card details had been stolen. Neiman Marcus, the department store, also said that it had discovered evidence that some of its customers’ cards may have been compromised last month.Target this week agreed to testify before Congress in February about the data breach, a House of Representatives subcommittee said on Wednesday.Representative Lee Terry, who chairs the commerce, manufacturing and trade subcommittee of the House committee on energy and commerce, said that the hearing would investigate what effects data breaches such as this have on consumers.The subcommittee said that it expected to take testimony from law enforcement officials and other witnesses, alongside Target representatives. Industry watchers have said that lawmakers are seeking to make an example of Target.“By examining these recent breaches and their consequences on consumers, we hope to gain a better understanding of the nature of these crimes and what steps can be taken to further protect information and limit cyber threats,” Mr Terry said.Although the Federal Trade Commission has in recent years brought legal action against companies that violate consumers’ privacy rights, there is no federal law that requires disclosure of security breaches to customers and law enforcement agencies.

Titular: Target data theft sounds wake-up call for retailers
Texto: Confessing to a cyber attack used to be an eerily quiet business. Shares could shrug and sales remain steady when confidential customer data or vital intellectual property was lost, as confused consumers and investors did not know how to react.But when Target admitted last week that the data of more than 70m customers were stolen in the Thanksgiving cyber attack, something unusual happened: it damaged its business. The US retailer warned sales would decline this quarter as the theft had scared some customers off. It has since acknowledged that patrons who shopped at the retailer outside of the November 27 and December 15 period may have also been affected.Cyber attacks are on the rise with cyber security experts warning retailers especially have become more vulnerable and still more could get caught up in this one breach. Neiman Marcus, the department store, said this week it discovered evidence some of its customers cards may have been compromised last month.Mike Fey, chief technology officer at Intel Security, formerly McAfee, said the Target breach, in which 40m credit card details were accessed, heralded a new era in cyber attacks, where companies would start to feel the impact as they now could be accused of being negligent.“It was a dirty little secret, I thought, in the investing world that if your factory burnt down you would have to quickly tell investors you lost a material asset, but if your super secret formula for your product is stolen you didn’t have to tell anybody,” he said.Until now, the threat has been so difficult to measure it has often been ignored. Victims often saw little financial impact and many companies did not even declare the attacks as a material change to their business.Nine out of 10 cyber security attacks had little or no impact on the share price of the victim, according to research done last year by law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, which warned that investors did not fully appreciate the dangers a company can face after a breach.Until the Target attack, the largest data breach on record for a retailer was in 2007 when 90m records were stolen from TJX Companies, the parent company of retailers TJ Maxx and TK Maxx.TJX sales continued to grow strongly at the time despite the attack and, unlike Target, the company did not say that customers were scared off by the hack. Shares remained flat in the weeks after it admitted to the attack.But by the end of the year, the breach had ended up costing the company more than $130m because of the extra cost of the investigation and settlements with banks, card issuers and customer class actions.There have recently been lawsuits where companies can sue partners such as banks or retailers for neglecting security, so Target could face a “fairly hefty price tag”, said Mr Fey. “Target has a whole set of penalties facing them from banks and retailers.”Customers and small banks have filed 70 class action lawsuits in 21 states and Washington DC, claiming Target did not sufficiently protect consumer data, said Tina Wolfson, a lawyer at Ahdoot & Wolfson who is bringing one of the cases. Target said it would not comment on pending litigation.Senator Richard Blumenthal and other lawmakers have called for Congress and the Federal Trade Commission to probe Target after the data breach. The FTC has the authority to hold businesses to account if their data security policies are not sufficiently stringent.Target is now offering customers a year of free credit and identity theft monitoring and has said those who have had purchases made fraudulently with their accounts will not be held responsible.For the companies there is no way to put in place reserves as there is no way to know how bad the damage could be or who is liable to pay for the cost of such breachesEven in Target’s case, shares were barely hit by the attack – falling 2.2 per cent after the first announcement and 1.2 per cent after the second – despite the company warning that earnings would be impacted.Brian Yarbrough, retail analyst at Edward Jones, said retailers have been concerned about cyber security for some time, but neither they nor sector analysts were factoring in financial hits as a result of data breaches, as potential losses were so difficult to predict.“For the companies there is no way to put in place reserves as there is no way to know how bad the damage could be or who is liable to pay for the cost of such breaches,” he said.Cyber security experts are warning that, once hackers have developed malware to attack the software behind a point-of-sale device, they are unlikely to stop at one large retailer.Patrick Peterson, chief executive of cyber security company Agari, said the Target attack should be a “wake-up call” to other retailers.“Once you have a very, very successful technique like this why wouldn’t you go after all the retailers?” he said. “This is an arms race where we see the bad guys pulling into the lead.”Bitsight, which tracks where cyber attacks originate to compile a credit rating-like cyber security score for companies, said 40 per cent of the Fortune 200 retailers, excluding supermarkets, had a worse score than Target on its index. The number of attacks on the retail sector rose over the past year, the company said.Joe Feldman, retail analyst at Telsey Advisory Group, said the biggest issue for retailers right now is the financial impact of nervous customers staying away. “With so much choice out there, you would just go to another retailer,” he said.

Titular: Target sales hit by data breach
Texto: A huge theft of payment card data from Target is causing financial harm to the US retailer as it admitted that its sales had been hit and more customers could be affected.Target said on Friday that due to the breach it expected like-for-like sales to be down 2.5 per cent from a year ago in the quarter to the end of January. The retailer also said that the names and contact details of up to 70m people could have been stolen, in addition to up to 40m whose credit card details it had previously said were vulnerable. It said it did not know how much overlap there was between the two groups.Target also cut its profit forecast as some customers avoided its stores due to fears of fraud.The theft has turned into a crisis for the discount chain at the worst time of year as it was locked in a battle with rivals for shoppers during a highly competitive festive shopping season.Target has been criticised for the way it has dealt with the crisis because, since its announcement of the breach on December 19, it has sent out several partial statements containing information that it has later revised.“The way they handled it is not really an ‘A’,” said Stacey Widlitz, an analyst at SW Retail Advisors. “It was drift, drift after the fact.”The theft has pointed to the continued vulnerability of big organisations to cybercriminals.Target said it would “attempt to contact” affected customers if it knew their email addresses, a move that Ms Widlitz questioned given that many would be on the lookout for scams.If I got an email from Target . . . am I going to open that email? Are you crazy?“If I got an email from Target . . . am I going to open that email? Are you crazy?” she said.Target said its sales had been stronger than expected before its announcement on December 19, but “meaningfully weaker than expected” since it announced the breach.It said it expected sales to be down between 2 per cent and 6 per cent for the remainder of the quarter.When Target announced the breach it said that no further data could be stolen, but the reassurance did not sway some consumers.Gregg Steinhafel, chief executive of Target, said: “I know that it is frustrating for our guests to learn that this information was taken and we are truly sorry they are having to endure this.”Ms Widlitz said that Mr Steinhafel’s job was not in jeopardy but that “he’s got a lot of explaining to do”.Target said shoppers would have “zero liability for the cost of any fraudulent charges arising from the breach”.Target shares fell 1.1 per cent to $62.65 on Friday.

Titular: Encrypted PIN data taken in Target breach
Texto: The theft of credit and debit card data from Target extended to encrypted personal identification numbers, the retailer said on Friday, acknowledging that the pre-Christmas hacking was worse than its first public assessment.Some 40m cards were affected in one of the biggest ever data breaches in the US, causing inconvenience for millions of shoppers at the peak of the holiday shopping season.Accessing PINs along with card data could potentially allow thieves to withdraw money at cash machines. However, the retailer said the information was “strongly encrypted” and “we remain confident that PIN numbers are safe and secure”.However, one banker warned that there was a risk that the PINs could be unencrypted and funds withdrawn from cardholders’ accounts.The Secret Service and justice department are investigating the hacking. Target announced a week ago that accounts had been accessed between November 27 and December 15.In the aftermath of the episode, banks including JPMorgan Chase placed limits on spending to mitigate the impact of any fraud stemming from the data breach. Customers’ cash withdrawals were first capped at $100 and card purchases at $300, causing trouble for last-minute Christmas shoppers. The limits were later relaxed.Shares in Target fell 0.5 per cent to $62.15 on Friday. The stock has modestly underperformed peers since news of the breach first emerged.John Kindervag, a security analyst at Forrester Research, said the encryption should hold though the fact that PIN data had been taken raised further questions about Target’s storage of information.“It shows that Target was aggregating a lot of data that was unnecessary for them in the back end,” he said.“Assuming they did key management OK everything is fine; there’s nothing to worry about,” he said. “We call that killing your data, devaluing it by proper encryption. Most standardised algorithms – despite all the things you see on TV – generally can’t be hacked or broken.”Target said: “Target does not have access to nor does it store the encryption key within our system. The PIN information is encrypted within Target’s systems and can only be decrypted when it is received by our external, independent payment processor. What this means is that the ‘key’ necessary to decrypt that data has never existed within Target’s system and could not have been taken during this incident.”Nonetheless, Mr Kindervag said: “If you used your debit card at Target it’s probably a good idea to change that PIN number.”

Titular: Target security breach hits 40m customer accounts
Texto: Thieves have stolen credit card data from up to 40m Target shoppers in a huge security breach that has hit the US retailer at the height of the holiday shopping season.The theft points to the continued vulnerability of big organisations to cybercriminals. Data security has become a top priority for companies and governments worried about protecting sensitive information.The theft could hardly have come at a worse time for the discount chain, the world’s eleventh biggest retailer by sales, which is locked in a battle with rivals for festive shoppers.The breach occurred between November 27 and December 15, a period that included the biggest shopping day of the year, Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving.In a message for customers on its website Target urged them to “remain vigilant for incidents of fraud and identity theft by regularly reviewing your account statements and monitoring free credit reports”.Edward Markey, a Democratic senator who is vocal on privacy issues, said: “Target shoppers should not have targets on their backs for data thieves …We need to quickly uncover the extent of the harm suffered by Target customers from this massive data breach and fix the security weaknesses exploited by these fraudsters.”A Target spokeswoman said the retailer had “hundreds of people” answering telephone calls from concerned shoppers, but she declined to comment on whether any fraud had already been detected.The theft affected only shoppers in its bricks-and-mortar stores, not transactions on its website, Target said. Security analysts say store check outs have become a major target for cybercriminals in recent years.The theft appeared to be one of the biggest breaches of data security in the retail sector since TJX Companies – a discount chain that owns TJ Maxx in the US and TK Maxx in the UK – said in 2007 that it had fallen victim to criminals.Federal prosecutors later said that the TJX case was part of a broader scheme in which hackers stole more than 41m credit and debit card numbers from a total of nine big retailers.Target said the information involved in its case included customer names, credit or debit card numbers, card expiration dates and CVV three-digit security codes.John Kindervag, a principal analyst with Forrester Research, said: “This is a breach that should have never happened.”He said the theft of CVV codes suggested that they were being stored, a practice banned by card brands. “Clearly by exposing CVV information Target has demonstrated a blatant disregard for . . . compliance regulations as well as card security best practices,” he said.Gregg Steinhafel, chief executive of Target, said: “We regret any inconvenience this may cause . . . We take this matter very seriously and are working with law enforcement to bring those responsible to justice.”Target said it had alerted the authorities and financial institutions as soon as it found out about the incident and that the theft had now ended.On the cusp of this weekend’s Super Saturday, one of the biggest shopping days of the year, the spokeswoman said: “Guests should feel confident shopping.”Target shares fell more than 2 per cent on Thursday in a flat market.

Titular: US Thanksgiving sales set to be down
Texto: US retail sales are likely to be down on last year in the four days from Thanksgiving to Sunday despite the early opening of stores and a surge in online spending, according to initial estimates.The National Retail Federation said on Sunday that it expected total spending over the long holiday weekend – when some stores opened earlier than ever on Thanksgiving night – to drop to $57.4bn from $59bn last year.It said 141m people were buying over the holiday weekend, up from 139m last year, but a survey of their shopping intentions indicated that their average spend would fall to $407 from nearly $424 last year.On Thanksgiving and Black Friday alone, sales at stores rose by a modest 2.3 per cent from last year, according to estimates from ShopperTrak, a research group.The retail federation’s estimates suggest that Saturday and Sunday were much lighter shopping days.ShopperTrak reiterated its longer-term forecast of a 2.4 per cent rise in sales in November and December as a whole. That would be the slimmest gain since 2009, when holiday sales were down from the previous year.Ecommerce continued to boom as more consumers opted to avoid the crowds and shop online, where many retailers offered the same “door buster” discounts they had in stores.On Thanksgiving, online sales climbed 18 per cent year-on-year to just over $1bn and on Black Friday they jumped 39 per cent to $1.9bn, according to analysis by Adobe Systems.Ecommerce extends beyond online-only businesses such as Amazon and eBay. Traditional retailers are taking more traffic away from their stores with their own websites. For example Target, a style-oriented discount chain, said it experienced twice as many online orders as on Thanksgiving last year.Despite improvements in labour and housing markets, retailers and economists say US consumers continue to be inhibited by economic uncertainty, rising living costs, confusion over healthcare and political gridlock in Washington.At malls and big box retail parks, shopper numbers on Black Friday itself were down 11.4 per cent from last year, ShopperTrak said, as consumers were lured by retailers that opened earlier than ever on Thanksgiving at 6pm or 8pm.Bill Martin, ShopperTrak’s founder, said it was expensive for retailers to open on Thanksgiving because they had to offer holiday pay and other incentives to employees and that would put their profitability in the spotlight.“You’ve got extra expenses and deep discounts, so the question is: did anyone make any money?” he said.Retailers typically begin the holiday season with a few loss-leading discounts, but they are carefully planned. Profitability often takes the biggest hit later in the season when they are forced to offer big unplanned discounts to offload products that have flopped.NPD, a research group, said the top-selling items on Thursday, Friday and Saturday were clothing, which accounted for 28 per cent of purchases, followed by toys at 11 per cent.The long Thanksgiving weekend accounts for about 10 per cent of retail sales in November and December, according to analysts at Cowen & Co.The holiday season can account for between 20 and 40 per cent of retailers’ annual revenues, said the National Retail Federation.

Titular: US retailers lack Christmas cheer
Texto: Target, Sears and Abercrombie & Fitch have joined a roll call of retailers reporting weak pre-Christmas results as the actions of management exacerbated the effects of a fragile economy.Target, the style-minded discount chain, posted a 0.9 per cent rise in like-for-like US sales that fell short of Wall Street forecasts on Thursday. It said its decision to enter Canada this year was eroding its profits far more than expected.Sears, a department store that hedge fund manager Eddie Lampert has been struggling to revive since 2004, reported a net loss of $534m for the three months to November 2 and said its like-for-like sales fell 3.1 per cent.Abercrombie & Fitch, a youth retailer that some analysts say has lost its fashion edge, reported a $15m net loss and a 14 per cent fall in US like-for-like sales. It warned that it expected weak sales to continue into the end-of-year shopping season.November and December are make-or-break months for retailers, when many make between 20 and 40 per cent of their annual sales.But many Americans are reluctant to splash out because of the fragile jobs market, rising living costs and uncertainty over healthcare bills under “Obamacare”, said Thom Blischok, chief retail strategist at Booz & Co. “We might call it an ‘underlying foundation of economic fear’,” he said.Target’s weak performance prompted the retailer to suspend its share buyback in the past quarter, a move it linked to its “commitment to maintain its strong investment-grade credit ratings”.The discount chain’s aggressive expansion into Canada has turned sour as its 124 stores in the country are sapping its profitability. Its net income of $341m for the past quarter translated into lower than expected earnings per share of 54 cents. The company said its Canada business had wiped 29 cents from that number.Reflecting investment costs and the discounts Target had to offer to sell excess inventory, the gross margin of its Canadian business – a key measure of profitability – was 14.8 per cent, versus 30 per cent in the US. Target shares fell 3.7 per cent to $64.03 on Thursday morning.Sears shares were also down – 1.5 per cent lower at $60.79 – after its results. Its total sales dropped $585m from a year ago to $8.3bn, reflecting the fall in like-for-like sales as well as the closure of some stores and the spin-off of others.Abercrombie & Fitch had already said it was not optimistic about the Christmas shopping season, so investors put its outlook to one side and focused on its earnings per share – excluding some hefty charges – of 52 cents, which surpassed expectations. Abercrombie shares edged up 0.3 per cent to $35.09.

Titular: Week in review, August 24
Texto:
A round up of some of the week’s most significant corporate events and news stories.Corporate person in the news: Meg Whitman, chief executive, Hewlett-PackardWhen Meg Whitman took on the top job at Hewlett-Packard nearly two years ago, people who knew her had one overriding question: Why?This week, with HP stumbling badly in its long-running turnround, that may be a question that she is also asking herself, writes Richard Waters.One of the few women to have risen to the top in Silicon Valley, Ms Whitman certainly did not need the recognition or the money.The fortune she reaped from her nine years at the helm of online marketplace eBay is estimated to be worth $1.9bn by Forbes, making the token $1 in salary she is paid by HP an irrelevance (though additional equity awards have lifted her annual income to more than $15m since she joined the company.)Ms Whitman has already used her personal wealth to build a new career well beyond the technology world. Her failed $144m bid as a Republican candidate for governor of California in 2010 turned out to be the most expensive run for statewide office in US history.Nor did the former eBay boss bring the sort of experience that many thought was needed to revive a venerable but faded name in US technology. She lacked either a background in business IT, or deep operational experience to get to grips with HP’s sprawling range of hardware, software and services businesses. Also, she had left eBay as its own fortunes were starting to wane, and the company required a turnround of its own under new chief John Donahoe.Pesky Brussels bureaucrats are depriving Europeans of brighter smiles with rules that prevent the sale of teeth-whitening products directly to consumers, said Procter & Gamble (a peddler of teeth-whitening products). It is lobbying for regulations to be relaxed, bringing Europe into line with the US, Brazil and China.Despite that, her determined and focused performance since taking on one of the toughest jobs in Silicon Valley has won her grudging respect even from some people who doubted her decision to take the job in the first place. She has remained very much on-message in trying to keep HP’s executives and its shareholders focused on the long and painstaking turnround, with the need for effective execution her overriding message rather than any big changes in strategy, according to one person who has worked with her.That made this week’s news particularly galling for the former eBay boss, as she admitted that “inconsistent execution” had been behind a slide in HP’s competitive position in two of its key markets, PCs and low-priced industry standard servers. After a stock price surge of nearly 80 per cent this year on hopes that HP’s revival was starting to take hold, it amounted to a major setback and admission of failure, leading to a shake-up among the company’s senior executives as Ms Whitman sought to tighten performance.Ms Whitman has herself survived at least one potential threat to her leadership, with three of the company’s directors quitting after shareholders expressed their unhappiness about the company’s disastrous acquisition of UK software company Autonomy in 2011. Despite being one of the HP directors who voted unanimously for that deal, Ms Whitman survived the investor rebellion.This week, she declared, HP was finally ready to go back on the acquisition trail again. So what are the risks of another big debacle from a deal gone bad? “Don’t worry about that,” she tried to assure the company’s shareholders earlier this week. “We are very focused and disciplined.”Vestas ousts chief executive as outlook turns favourableVestas bowed to investor pressure on Wednesday and ousted Ditlev Engel (pictured) as chief executive of the Danish wind turbine manufacturer, writes Richard Milne.The move revealed that Bert Nordberg, Vestas’ chairman for the past year, is the man calling the shots in efforts to pull the group out of a difficult few years.Mr Nordberg now has a chief executive he knows well: Anders Runevad, a former colleague from both Ericsson and its mobile phone joint venture with Sony. Mr Runevad will take over a lossmaking company that has been battered by multiple profit warnings.Dawn Airey, the former chairman and chief executive of Channel Five, is to join Yahoo as head of its European operations. The
52-year-old earned the affectionate sobriquets “Scarey Airey” and “Zulu Dawn” from some former colleagues, but has insisted she is “tough with a soft centre”.Many of the past problems have now been cleared up: Vestas, which lost its crown as the world’s biggest wind company to General Electric last year, now sports an entirely new executive team. Mr Nordberg has switched the focus away from revenue growth to cash flow and profitability. But two big investor lawsuits – one in the US and one in Europe – still hang over the company.Mr Runevad will benefit from a more optimistic attitude from investors towards wind companies, especially after the US renewed its subsidy regime this year. Vestas’ share price has quadrupled since its lows in November, although they are still down 85 per cent from 2008.Mr Engel paid the price for his decision to keep building new factories and hiring workers after the financial crisis. He was then forced to cut a third of the workforce as part of a deep restructuring needed to fend off Vestas’ creditors.Bleak results point to belt tightening by US shoppersWhile the talk in the markets is of an improving US economy that will in due course lift interest rates, it seems many Americans are not feeling good enough to splash out at the mall, writes Barney Jopson.That was the message of bleak results from US retailers this week, which stoked pessimism about the crucial end-of-year shopping season.Clothes retailers were the nexus of the bad news. Sales in the quarter to early August fell at the teen fashion retailers Abercrombie & Fitch and American Eagle, as well as the department stores JC Penney and Sears, where consumer caution aggravated busted company strategies.They followed declining sales last week at Walmart, the world’s biggest retailer by sales, and Macy’s, another department store whose recent run of good form ground to a sudden halt.On average retailers have fallen short of Wall Street’s profit expectations by 1 per cent, according to Retail Metrics, a research group.Target managed to report a slim rise in sales; it was less than Wall Street wanted. Its chief executive spoke for many when he said he expected consumer spending to be cautious for the rest of the year “in the face of ongoing household budget pressures”.The gloom, however, was not unremitting. At Home Depot and Lowe’s sales were up by double-digit percentages, as they benefited from spending linked to a rebounding housing market. The conclusion: Americans have not stopped spending entirely.Glencore Xstrata chief insists deal will pay offGlencore Xstrata’s first interim results as a combined group this week produced a $7.7bn writedown that inevitably led to questions as to whether Ivan Glasenberg overpaid to bring Xstrata’s mining assets into the commodities trading house he has led for more than a decade, writes James Wilson.Glencore’s deal to acquire Xstrata – the biggest ever between mining groups – took more than a year to complete, a period during which the sector fell out of favour with investors. Prices of some mined commodities have fallen amid signs that the China-led resources boom has slowed.Mr Glasenberg defended the logic of the deal and insisted it would still pay off for Glencore.The impairment stems from the difference between the valuation now attributed to some parts of Xstrata – particularly its early-stage projects – and the price paid, as measured by Glencore’s stock price when the all-share deal was completed in May.Highlighting the downturn in mining, Glencore Xstrata’s interim earnings were down 28 per cent before interest and tax, on a pro-forma basis assuming the companies had been combined since the start of the year.However, Mr Glasenberg promised Glencore would deliver more annual synergies from the deal than the $500m so far estimated.Next month the group is set to explain details of those larger synergies and say where it expects further growth to come from.Recruitment drive targets dealmakers and tradersA number of investment banks have started to expand their European franchises by hiring dealmakers and traders, raising hopes that the jobs market for bankers has reached a turning point, writes Daniel Schäfer.Nomura, Citigroup and Bank of America are among a number of banks that have started hiring in Europe in recent months, in a sign that recruitment is picking up after a two-year cull that saw thousands lose their jobs.Recruiters said they are at their busiest in a number of years as banks add new staff in revenue-generating positions in areas ranging from M&A advice to equities trading. It came as data showed that the rate of job losses in the global investment banking sector has slowed significantly.Staff levels in the front offices of the 10 largest investment banks fell 0.8 per cent between the first and second quarter to 54,165, according to data that will be published on Thursday by Coalition, the research company.This was less than half the rate than in the first three months of the year and comes after two years of drastic job cuts.A number of banks are beginning to expand in areas where they are making good returns.After a year of staff reductions Nomura, the Japanese bank, is looking to make senior hires for its European sector coverage and for its regional offices, people close to the situation said.It is also adding mid-level bankers to its leveraged finance team.

Titular: Target warns of cautious consumers
Texto: Target forecast that consumers would remain “cautious” in their spending for the rest of the year, as the US discount retailer reported weaker-than-expected quarterly US sales.The 1.2 per cent rise in US like-for-like sales in the quarter to August 3 nonetheless beat its biggest rival Walmart, which announced a fall in sales last week. Target also met Wall Street profit expectations, a feat several other retailers have failed to achieve.For the full year, however, it said on Wednesday that it expected profits to be “near the low end” of its previous guidance range of $4.70 to $4.90 per share.US retailers have reported a series of gloomy results that suggest improvements in the labour and housing markets are not giving many consumers enough confidence to spend more.At the 65 retailers that have reported results for the past quarter, profits have been on average 0.7 per cent below Wall Street expectations, according to Retail Metrics, a research group.Gregg Steinhafel, Target chief executive, said: “For the balance of this year, our US outlook envisions continued cautious spending by consumers in the face of ongoing household budget pressures.”Also on Wednesday, Staples, the office supplies retailer facing tough competition from ecommerce, said its sales fell 2 per cent to $5.3bn from a year ago in the past quarter. Its earnings per share came in two cents short of market expectations at 16 cents.Home improvement, however, continued to stand out as a bright spot. Lowe’s, a store shoppers turn to kit out new houses and renovate old ones, reported a 9.6 per cent rise in sales at stores open at least a year. That followed even steeper sales growth on Tuesday at its main rival Home Depot.At Target, Mr Steinhafel said an increase in US income tax this year continued to affect consumer spending, particularly among lower-income households.“Recent job growth numbers have been encouraging, but labour force participation and income growth remain weak,” he said.Target shares fell 3.8 per cent to $65.39 on Thursday.It made a net profit of $611m, or 95 cents per share, down 10 per cent from the same period last year partly because of the cost of entering the Canadian market, where Target has opened 68 stores so far this year in a search for new growth.Faye Landes, analyst at Cowen & Co, pointed out that Target’s gross margin in Canada – a key measure of profitability – fell to 31.6 per cent from 38 per cent in the previous quarter, a possible reflection of intensifying competition.In the past quarter, Loblaw, Canada’s biggest retailer by sales, acquired the pharmacy chain Shoppers Drug Mart for $12bn while Sobeys, another local chain, bought Safeway’s Canadian stores for $5.7bn.

Titular: Target / Walmart: wagers, please
Subtitular: The market is ignoring the differences between the two. Does this make sense?
Texto: For Americans, there is something uniquely depressing about bad quarterly results from Walmart. The company employs 1.3m people in the US, a per cent of the employed population. It sells Americans over a quarter-trillion dollars of goods annually, more than a 10th of all retail sales. So when Walmart says its US comparable-store sales did not grow and cuts its growth targets, as it did last week, everyone shivers a bit.Investors in Target – which reports its own results on Wednesday – don’t just shiver. Since Walmart’s bad numbers, Target’s shares have fallen almost as much as its larger rival’s. For most of the past two years, in fact, the stocks have been in step – despite big differences between the two. Most importantly, Target is slightly upscale of Walmart. This is working in its favour, judging by comparable-store sales in the US: over the eight prior quarters, Target’s had averaged 2.7 per cent, to Walmart’s 1.4 per cent. Walmart makes a third of its revenue internationally; Target is only now going abroad– to exotic Canada. Walmart is more focused on food (half of US sales) than Target (a fifth). Target, finally, lacks a warehouse club division to match Walmart’s Sam’s Club.The market has looked at these contrasts and decided that, for now, they do not amount to much. Both trade at about 14 times forward earnings (two years ago, they both traded at 11). Does this make sense?The two companies have not always traded together: during the 2008 tumult, down-market, staples-driven, geographically diverse Walmart did radically better. Target bounced in the happier years that followed. So if the American consumer is slipping backwards again (as demonstrated by soft results not only at Walmart but at mid-market Macy’s and fancy Nordstrom, too) Walmart may merit a premium. Against this, Target’s partisans will point to its greater growth and its opportunities abroad. The parallel valuations allow for a cheerful little wager: pessimists take Walmart, optimists Target. Place your bets.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: US consumers’ tight budget takes toll on Target sales
Texto: Target added to signs that US consumers remain on tight budgets by reporting an unexpected fall in sales following similarly disappointing results from Walmart last week.The mass market retailer, which serves a slightly wealthier clientele than cut-price Walmart, also reported profits that fell short of market expectations for the three months to March 4 and cut its earnings guidance for the year. Target shares fell 2.5 per cent in premarket trading in New York.The group’s like-for-like US sales fell 0.6 per cent in the quarter, although it had said in mid-April that it expected them to be flat. Its net sales were $16.7bn, up 1 per cent from a year ago, partly thanks to the opening of 24 new stores in Canada.Target blamed the decline on cold spring weather – a factor whose influence is subject to debate in retail – which it said depressed sales of clothes and other “weather-sensitive” product categories.When Walmart reported a 1.1 per cent fall in like-for-like sales last week, it blamed a rise in the payroll tax rate this year, delayed tax refunds from last year and lower than expected food inflation, as well as the weather.Target reported net income of $498m, or 77 cents per share, which was less than Wall Street’s forecast of 87 cents per share and 26 per cent lower than a year ago.“While we are disappointed in our first quarter performance, we remain confident in our strategy,” said Gregg Steinhafel, Target’s chief executive.The group cut its full-year earnings per share guidance to $4.70 to $4.90 from $4.85 to $5.05.

Titular: Target set to open 24 stores in Canada
Texto: Target will open its first 24 stores in Canada by early April and vowed to invest a further $1.5bn in the country this year as the retailer seeks to offset weak sales in the US.The discount chain has been preparing to open in Canada since buying leases on about 200 premises two years ago, but it said on Wednesday that the expansion would reduce profits this year by more than expected.Target, renowned for bringing cheap chic to low-price retail, confirmed on Wednesday that it planned to have 124 stores in Canada by the end of the year as it reported meagre US sales and profits for the Christmas shopping season.Doug Stephens, president of Retail Prophet consulting, said Canada was a “tremendous opportunity” for Target because it was much less crowded than the US, where there is a surfeit of shops and ecommerce is expanding rapidly.“There’s been an absolute dearth of competition in Canada,” he said. “The whole country has been owned by a handful of national chains. We haven’t had any shake-up since Walmart came in in the 1990s. It’s been static.”Because it will sell both general merchandise and groceries, Target’s competition will include Sears, another US peer, and Loblaw, Canada’s biggest grocery chain by sales.Target declined to provide a revenue forecast for its Canadian business, but said expansion costs would reduce its earnings per share by 45 cents in 2013. It forecast earnings per share for the year of $4.70 to $4.90.Target’s like-for-like sales in the US grew just 0.4 per cent in the three months to February 2, worse than the 1 per cent growth reported last week by Walmart, its main rival, which also disappointed investors.Gregg Steinhafel, Target chief executive, said the group faced “a highly promotional retail environment and continued consumer uncertainty”. Consumer spending this year has been damped by a rise in payroll taxes and delayed income tax refunds from 2012.Target’s net profit for the quarter fell 2 per cent from a year ago to $961m, translating to earnings per share of $1.47 that were one cent short of consensus estimates. Target shares fell 1 per cent to $63.41 on Wednesday.In January 2011, Target agreed to pay C$1.82bn to acquire leases on up to 220 sites operated by Zellers, a fading Canadian discount retailer.Most of US retail is parochial compared with other sectors of business, but a lack of domestic sales growth is prompting more companies to contemplate downsizing and expansion elsewhere.Walmart is by far the most adventurous, having built an international business with $135bn of sales last year in 26 countries.Target, based in Minneapolis, is facing competition from Amazon and has been more aggressive than most in cutting its commercial ties with the online rival – it no longer sells Amazon’s Kindles.

Titular: US holiday retail sales disappoint
Texto: Limited spending by US consumers produced a lacklustre holiday shopping season for many retailers, which are likely to face pressure on profits and questions over whether they should have fewer stores.Target reported flat December sales while the owner of Victoria’s Secret for once fell short of sales expectations. Macy’s, despite decent results, said it would close six stores this year.Sales at stores open for at least a year rose on average 2.3 per cent in December among the 19 retailers that reported figures on Thursday, according to Thomson Reuters. That compares with a 3.5 per cent rise in the same month last year and headline inflation currently running at 1.8 per cent.December is the most important month of the year for retailers and in a desperate effort to win consumer dollars – even at the cost of profits – many stores resorted to big price cuts in the days before Christmas.Joel Bines, a consultant at AlixPartners, said: “Essentially [retailers] averted disaster. That’s the best you can say about this holiday season.” Excluding drug stores, like-for-like sales were up 4.5 per cent.Retail Metrics, a research group, said December sales were not as disappointing as some had feared, but had been hit by a stream of negative news, including worries over the “fiscal cliff”, winter storms and the Newtown massacre.The S&P index of big retailers rose 0.9 per cent on Thursday.Walter Loeb, a veteran retail consultant, said the holiday sales figures would revive questions over whether the US has more stores than it needs in a fragile economy.“You have to add that many people who shop at the promotional stores also shop on the internet, where sales were abounding from the 1st to the 31st of December,” he said.Just before Christmas, research group ComScore said ecommerce spending was up 16 per cent from a year ago in November and December.Barnes & Noble, the bookseller that is facing a bigger threat from digital commerce than most, reported a 10.9 per cent fall in sales at its stores and on its website in the nine-week holiday period to the end of December.Last week Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, spent $89.5m to buy a 5 per cent stake in Nook Media, a joint venture between Barnes & Noble and Microsoft which runs the Nook ebook division.Target is the US’s second-biggest general retailer by sales after Walmart and analysts had expected it to report like-for-like sales growth of 1.5 per cent. Instead it reported flat sales after a fall in the number of shoppers was not offset by an increase in the average dollar spend.Limited Brands, which owns Victoria’s Secret, reported a lower-than-expected 3 per cent rise in like-for-like sales in December. Macy’s, a department store, reported like-for-like sales up 4.1 per cent as it announced the closure of six “underperforming” stores.Gap, which reported a 5 per cent rise in December sales, also announced that it was moving upmarket by paying $130m to buy Intermix, a women’s fashion boutique. Its 32 stores in North America give Gap a foothold in the luxury sector, where sales have generally been stronger than in mid-market fashion.December’s best performers included Costco, a warehouse club, where like-for-like sales rose 9 per cent from a year ago, and Nordstrom, a high-end department store where like-for-like sales were up 8.6 per cent – both ahead of expectations.

Titular: Facebook defies Wall Street gloom
Texto: Facebook shares jumped higher on Monday as the social networking site continued to win over investors on Wall Street who were once sceptical of the prospects for its mobile business.The gains came as the broader US equity market retreated in the week’s first trading session, after stocks last week had their best weekly gain since June.The S&P 500 fell 0.2 per cent to 1,406.29. The Dow Jones Industrial Average moved 0.3 per cent lower to 12,967.37. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3 per cent to 2,976.78.Facebook rose 8.1 per cent to $25.94 as analysts at Bernstein Research said the market was underestimating the company’s potential revenue growth for the next two years, which would be driven by its mobile business.Carlos Kirjner, analyst at Bernstein, raised his price target for the company’s shares to $33 and changed his rating to “buy” from “hold”.Mr Kirjner highlighted innovations and changes by the company to adapt the site to mobile devices as a source of strength for its future revenues.One of the big concerns for investors has been the company’s ability to increase sales through advertising on mobile devices as users shift away from personal computers.Shares in Facebook have dropped some 31.7 per cent since their public float in May but have recovered in recent weeks since reaching their all-time low of $17.73 in September.Wall Street stocks fell throughout the morning session on Monday as retailers pared their gains from last week.Despite reports highlighting a strong start to the holiday selling period, the S&P 500 retailing index – up 4.7 per cent last week – retreated 0.2 per cent.A report at the weekend said online sales rose more than 20 per cent with the start of the Christmas shopping season.But the news was not enough to boost shares in some of the country’s largest retailers. Walmart lost 0.4 per cent to $69.91, and Target fell 2.6 per cent to $62.78.Amazon rose 1.6 per cent to $243.79 as the online retailer said it would issue its first bond in more than a decade. The company’s website was the most visited online retail site during Black Friday, according to reports.Abercrombie & Fitch rose 0.5 per cent to $44.60 as analysts said the teenage clothing retailer was one of the biggest beneficiaries from the start to holiday shopping last Friday.“Traffic is off to a strong start this holiday season and after a year of many challenges, we believe they have turned a corner,” said Paul Lejuez, analyst at Nomura. “[Abercrombie] stores were among the most crowded in the mall on Black Friday.”Meanwhile, investors continued to assess the likelihood that politicians in Washington would resolve the fiscal cliff of tax cuts and spending rises.David Bianco, equity market strategist at Deutsche Bank, said: “The S&P should rally as it becomes clear that the fiscal cliff will be averted and US GDP growth will stay positive in the first half of next year.”Apple shares continued to march higher after falling to a multi-month low earlier in November. The iPhone and iPad maker moved 3.2 per cent higher to $589.53.Citigroup launched coverage of the company at the weekend and assigned three analysts to cover Apple, which ranks as the largest company in the world by market value.The analysts said one of the primary challenges that the company faced in its next few quarters was from low-end smartphone makers.The S&P 500 financial sector index lost 0.5 per cent as a Financial Times report said global banking regulators were looking to force banks to hold more capital following several high-profile scandals.JPMorgan Chase, hit by more than $6bn in losses through a massive credit derivatives position earlier this year, fell 0.5 per cent to $40.88.Other bulge-bracket Wall Street banks also declined. Bank of America lost 0.7 per cent to $9.84 and Citigroup moved 1.3 per cent lower to $35.57.Knight Capital, the electronic trading and market-making company, gained 13.3 per cent to $2.82 after weekend reports said it was looking at acquisition offers.Its shares have fallen more than 70 per cent since having a $461.1m trading loss in August because of a software glitch.

Titular: Online sales soar on Black Friday
Texto: Online sales jumped more than 20 per cent in the US at the traditional start of the Christmas shopping season as the growing use of tablet computers fuelled “couch commerce”.Black Friday internet sales climbed 26 per cent on a year ago, to $1bn, according to ComScore, while IBM, using a different methodology, recorded a 21 per cent increase.The figures came as the US retail federation reported stronger sales across all forms of retail than many analysts had expected, suggesting that improvements in the job and stock markets could be boosting spending.The most visited retail site on Friday was Amazon, the dominant internet-only retailer, but next in the top five were the websites of three bricks-and-mortar stores – Walmart, Best Buy and Target – followed by Apple, according to ComScore.Black Friday is the busiest shopping day of the year but Capital Economics research has shown it is not a reliable indicator of total holiday season spending, which can account for 20-40 per cent of retailers’ annual sales.The ease of shopping on tablet computers encouraged more so-called “couch commerce”, with purchases on mobile devices accounting for 16 per cent of all online transactions and iPads alone making up 10 per cent, IBM said.But although more people took to the internet, the average spend per person fell 4.7 per cent to $181 and the average number of purchases fell 12 per cent to 5.6, according to IBM.The National Retail Federation said total retail sales rose 13 per cent from last year to $59bn over the four days from Thanksgiving to Sunday.Although the 139m people who shopped were 8m more than last year, they were fewer than the NRF’s forecast of 147m.After the Thanksgiving weekend, US retailers typically offer a blizzard of online discounts on what has come to be known as Cyber Monday, but its relevance has been diluted by the decision of many to start unveiling deals last week.
